editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Acted in the year 1635. by the then company of revels, at Salisbury court.
div.quote: Hic totus voloride at libellus. Mart.
div.p: Printed by I. Okes, for Francis Constable, and are to be sold at his shops in Kings-street at the sign of the goat, and in Westminster-hall. 1640.

div.head: To the right honourable William Earl of Newcastle, etc. governor to the prince his highness.
div.p:
Your favourable construction of my poor labours commanded my service to your honour, and, in that, betrayed your worth to this dedication: I am not ignorant how far unworthy my best endeavours are of your least allowance; yet let your lordship be pleased to know you, in this, share but the inconveniences of the most renowned princes as you partake of their glories: and I doubt not, but it will more divulge your noble disposition
to the world, when it is known you can freely pardon an officious trespass against your goodness. Caesar had never been commended for his clemency, had there not occasion been offered, wherein he might show, how willingly he could forgive: I shall thank my fortune, if this weak presentation of mine shall any way increase the glory of your name among good men, which is the chiefest aim and only study of

closer.signed: Your honour's devoted servant. Richard Brome.

div.head: To his deserving friend Mr. Richard Brome on his sparagus garden, a comedy.

lg.l: Whatever walk I in your garden use,
Breeds my delight, and makes me love thy muse
For the designment; sith I cannot spy
A prospect, which doth more invite mine eye:
I'm in a maze, and know not how to find
A freedom that will more delight my mind,
Than this imprisonment within thy bower,
Where hours seem minutes, and each day an hour,
Nor, were my stay perpetual, could I grieve,
Where such rare fruits mine appetite relieve.
The envious critic would recant to see
How much oppressed is every virgin tree
With her own burthen: leeks, and acornes here
Are food for critics; but the choicer cheer,
For those, can relish delicates I might
In praising of thy worth, be infinite:
But thou art modest and disdain it to hear
A tedious, glorious, needless character
Of thee ▪ and of thy muse: yet I could say,
(Give me but leave) it is no common play .
Within thy plot of ground, no weed doth spring,
To hurt the growth of any underling:
Nor is thy labyrinth confused, but we
In that disorder, may proportion see:
Thy herbs are physical, and do more good.
In purging humours, than Some's letting blood.

div.head: To the author on his sparagus garden.

lg.l: What dost mean, that thus thou dost entice
Thy lovers, thus to walk in paradise?
Most skilful artist! that so well dost know
To plant, for profit, as for outward show
For on thy sparagus are thoroughly pleased
Our intellects; others scarce ▪ hunger eased.
The wisest of the age shall hither come,
And think their time well spent as was their sum.
The sqint-eyed critic that such care does take,
To look for that he loatheth to partake:
Now crossing his warped nature shall be kind,
And vexing grieve 'cause he no fault can find.
The ignorant of the times that do delight,
Not in a play, but how to waste daylight,
Shall resort hither, till that you descry,
With pleasure, smiling April in each eye.
Alcinous' garden, which each day did spring,
And her loved fruit unto perfection bring,
Ought not compare with this: here men did grow:
Such care thy art and labour did bestow
For man's well-being, and anew create,
And poise them up above a needy fate.
Is it not pity ought should hurt this spring?
(A serpent in a garden's no new thing)
Yet wisely hath thy goodness took a care,
He should sting none, but who censorious are.
He, that his wonted modesty retains,
And never set a price upon his brains
Above your judgements; nor did ever strive
By arrogance or ambition to achieve
More praise unto himself, or more applause
Unto his scenes, than such, as know the laws
Of comedy do give; he only those 〈◊〉
Now prays may scan his verse, and weigh his prose:
Yet thus far he thinks meet to let you know
Before you see't, the subject is so low,
That to expect high language, or much cost,
Were a sure way, now, to make all be lost.
Pray look for none: he'll promise such hereafter,
To take your graver judgements, now your laughter
Is all he aims to move. I had more to say - —
The title, too, may prejudice the play.
It says the sparagus garden; if you look
To feast on that, the title spoils the book.
We have yet a taste of it, which he doth lay
I'th midst o'th journey, like a bait by th' way:
Now see with candour: as our poet's free,
Pray let be so your ingenuity.
At first we made no boast, and still we fear,
We have not answered expectation here,
Yet give us leave to hope, as hope to live,
That you will grace, as well as justice give.
We do not dare your judgements now: for we
Know lookers on more than the gamesters see;
And whate'er poets write, we act, or say,
'Tis only in your hands to crown a play.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: With me gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Only a few neighbourly and friendly words sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: O you are most friendly welcome good Mr. Gilbert Gilawire, and Mr. Walter Chamlet I take ye to be.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: The same sir at your service.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Your fathers both were my good neighbours indeed; worthy and well reputed members of the city while they lived: but that may be read upon the hospital walls, and gates; it is enough for me to say they loved me: Sanson Touchwood! and I were a wretch if I should not honour their memory in their happy succession: again gentlemen you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Yet you may be pleased sir to remember, though our fathers were both loving friends to you, yet they were sometimes at odds one with another.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: True, true, ever at odds: they were the common talk of the town for a pair of wranglers; still at strife for one trifle or other: they were at law loggerheads together, in one match that held 'em tugging tone the tother by the purse-strings a matter of nine years, and all for a matter of nothing. They coursed one another from court to court, and through every court temporal and spiritual; and held one another play till they lost a thousand pound a man to the lawyers, and till it was very sufficiently and judged that your father was one fool, and your father was another fool. And so again gentlemen you are welcome: now your business.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: You may now be pleased sir to remember that our fathers grew friends at last.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Heaven forbid else.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And note the cause, the ground of their reconciliation, which was upon the love, betwixt me and this gentleman's sister. My father's son married his father's daughter, and our two fathers grew friends, and wise men again.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: To the point good gentlemen, yet you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Troth sir the point is this: you know (And the town has ta'en sufficient notice of it) that there has been a long contention betwixt you and old Mr. Striker your neighbour —

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p:
And the cause or ground of your quarrel (For ought anybody
knows but yourselves) may be as trivial, as that which was derided in our fathers.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Are you there with me?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And great hopes there are, and wagers laid by your friends on both sides, that you two will be friends.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I'll hold you an hundred pounds of that.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Nay, more, that Mr. Striker will be willing to give his grandchild to your son, so you'll give your consent.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And your coming is to persuade that, is it not? if it be so, speak; deal plainly with me gentlemen, whilst yet you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: Insooth it is so, we come to negotiate the match for your son, and your friendship with old Mr. Striker.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: You are not welcome.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: But when you weigh the reasons, and consider the perfect love of the young pair, and how the world will praise your reconciliation, and bless the providence, that made their loves the means to work their parents charity.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Again you are not welcome.

lg.l: Yourself but now commended the atonement
Of our two fathers, wrought by the same means:
I mean my marriage with his sister here
Against as great an opposition.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: But our fathers loved their children.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Your fathers were a couple of doting fools, and you a pair of saucy knaves; now you are not welcome: and more than so, get you out of my doors.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Will you sir, by your wilfulness, cast away your son?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: My son? no son of mine, I have cast him off already for casting an eye upon the daughter of mine enemy: let him go, let him pack; let him perish: he comes not within these doors, and you, that are his fine spoken spokesmen, get you off of my ground I charge you.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: We are gone sir: only but wishing you Mr. Touchwood to remember that your son's your son.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p:
Indefinitely not sir, until he does not only renounce all interest in the love of that baggage; but do some extraordinary mischief in that family to right me for the trespass he has
done; and so win my good opinion, till which be done a daily curse of mine he shall not miss; and so you may inform him.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: What an uncharitable wretch is this?

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: The touchiest piece of Touchwood that e'er I met withal.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I feared we should inflame him.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: All the comfort is, his son may yet outlive him.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: But the danger is, his father may disinherit him

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: He cannot be so devilish; here comes his son, a gentleman of so sweet a disposition, and so contrary to his crabbed sire, that a man who never heard of his mother's virtue might wonder who got him for him.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Not at all I assure you, same is his father's noun son: for the old man you see, is gentle enough, till he be incensed; and the son being moved, is as fiery as the father.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: But he is very seldom and slowly moved; his father often and of the sudden.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I prithee wouldst thou have green wood take fire as soon as that which is old and sere?

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: He is deep in thought.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Over head and ears in his Mrs. contemplation.

lg.l: To disobey a father, is a crime
In any son unpardonable. Is this rule
So general that it can bear no exception?
Or is a father's power so illimitable,
As to command his son's affections?
And so control the conqueror of all men
Even love himself? no: he, that enterprises
So great a work, forgets he is a man;
And must in that forget he is a father,
And so if he forgo his nature, I
By the same law may leave my piety.
But stay, I would not lose myself in following
This wild conceit

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: How now Sam, whither away?

lg.l: I was but casting how to find the way
Unto myself. Can you direct me gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: Yes, yes; your father has told us the way.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ha you had conference with him? ha ye? speak.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Marry sir ha' we, and I think to purpose.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ha you won ought upon him to my advantage?

lg.l: As much as may restore you to acquaintance
With him again, can you but make good use on't.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Pray do not trifle with me; tell me briefly.

lg.l: Briefly he says you must not dare to see him;
Nor hope to receive blessing to the value
Of a new threepence, till you disclaim your love
In your fair Annabell; and not only so,
But you must do some villainous mischievous act
To vex his adversary, her grandfather;
Or walk beneath his curse in banishment.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A most uncharitable and unnatural sentence.

lg.l: But think withal it is your father, that
Makes this decree; obey him in the excecution:
He has a great estate, you are his only son:
Do not lose him, your fortune, and yourself
For a frail piece of beauty: shake her off;
And do some notable thing against her house,
To please your father
The devil speaks it in thee,
And with this spell I must conjure him out.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: O friend you ▪ are too violent.

lg.l: He's too desperate,
To urge me to an act of such injustice.
Can her fair love, to whom my faith is given,
Be answered with so loud an injury?
Or can my faith so broken yield a sound
Less terrible than thunder, to affright
All love and constancy out of the breast
Of every virgin that shall hear the breach
Of my firm faith?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Be not so passionate.

lg.l: I have no further power to do an outrage
against that family to whom my heart
Is linked, than to rip out this troubled heart
The only ominous cause, indeed, of all.
My over passionate father's cruelty; and that
(If I must needs do an injurious office)
Alone, shall be my act to calm his fury.
Prithee blow o'er this passion; thou wert wont
To affect wit, and canst not be a lover
Truly without it. Love is wit itself,
And through a thousand lets will find a way
To his desired end.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: The ballet taught you that.

lg.l: Well said, love will find out the way:
I see thou art coming to thyself again,
Can there no shift, no witty slight be found
(That have been common in all times and ages)
To blind the eyes of a weak-sighted father,
And reconcile these dangerous differences
But by bloodshedding, or outrageous deeds,
To make the feud the greater? recollect
Thyself good Sam; my house, my purse, my counsel
Shall all be thine, and what shall be thy friend.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: Let me entreat your friendship.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: And me your pardon.

lg.l: So, so, all friends; let's home and there consult
To lay the tempest of thy father's fury;
Which cannot long be dangerous, 'tis but like
A storm in April, spent in swift extremes,
When straight the sun shoots forth his cheerful beams.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You will not assault me in mine own house? I hope you will not; nor urge me beyond my patience with your borroughing attempts #! good sir Hugh Money-lacks I hope you will not.

lg.l: I hope I moved you not, but in fair language sir;
Nor spoke a syllable that might offend you.
I have not used the word of loan, or borrowing;
Only some private conference I requested.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Private conference! A new coined word for borrowing of money; I tell you, your very face, your countenance (Though it be glossed with knighthood) looks so borrowingly, that the best words you give me are as dreadful as stand and deliver, and there I think I was w'ye. I am plain w'ye sir, old will Striker I.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: My father striker, I am bold to call you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Your father! no, I desire no such near acquaintance with you, good sir Hugh Money-lacks: you are a knight and a noble gentleman, I am but an esquire and out of debt; and there I think I was w'ye again ▪

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I shall be with you anon, when you have talked yourself out of breath.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I had the honour to be your worship's father in law when time was, that your knighthood married and ladyfied a poor daughter of mine: but yet she had five thousand pounds in her purse if you please to remember it; and as I remember you had then fourteen hundred a year: but where is it now? and where is my daughter now? poor abused innocent; your riotousness abroad, and her long night watches at home shortened her days, and cast her into her grave — and 'twas not long before all your estate was buried too; and there I was w'ye again I take it: but that could not fetch her again.

lg.l: No sir, I wish my life might have excused
Hers, far more precious: never had a man
A juster cause to mourn.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Nor mourned more justly, it is your only wearing; you have just none other: nor have had means to purchase better any time these seven years as I take it . by which means you have got the name of the mourning knight; and there I am sure I was w'ye.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Sir, if you will not be pleased to hear my desires to you, let me depart without your derision.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p:
Even when you please, and whither you please good sir Hugh Money-lacks: my house shall be no enchanted castle to detain your knight-errandship from your adventures. I hope
your errand hither was but for your dinner; and so far forth (And especially at your going forth) you are welcome. Your daughter I do keep, and will for her poor mother's sake; (That was my daughter) peace be with her — she shall be no more a trouble to you; nor be your child any longer: I have made her mine; I will adopt her into mine own name, and make her a striker; she shall be no more a money-lack, and if she please me well in matching with a husband, I know what I will do for her.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Do you thank me sir, I assure you you need not; for I mean so to order her estate, and bind it up in that trust that you shall never finger a farthing on't: am I w'ye sir?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I cannot choose but thank you though in behalf of my child.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Call her your child again, or let me but hear that you suffer her to ask you a bare blessing, I'll send her after you upon adventures sir knight : and who shall give a portion with her then? or what can she hope from a father that groans under the weight of a knighthood for want of means to support it?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I ▪ shall find means to live without your trouble hereafter.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You may, you may; you have a wit sir Hugh, and a projective one; what, have you some new project a foot now, to out-go that of the hand-barrows? what call you 'em the sedams? o cry you mercy, cry you mercy; I heard you had put in for a share at the asparagus Ga den: or that at least you have a pension thence; to be their gather guest and bring 'em custom, and that you play the fly of the new inne-there; and sip with all companies: am I w'ye there sir?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You may be when you please sir; I can command the best entertainment there for your money.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: In good time sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
In the mean time sir, I had no mind to beg nor borrow of you, and though you will not ▪ give me leave to call you father, nor my daughter my daughter, yet I thought it might become my care to advertise you (That have taken the care of her from me) of a danger that will much afflict you, if it be not
carefully prevented.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You have an adversary —

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: But one that I know, the rascal my neighbour Touchwood.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: There I am w'ye sir, I am informed that his only son is an earnest suitor to your daughter: (I must not call her mine)

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: That there is a deep secret love betwixt 'em; and that they have had many private meetings: and a stolen match very likely to be made if you prevent it not.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Can this be true?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Give me but a piece from you, and if by due examination you find it not so, I'll never see your face again till you send for me.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: To be rid of you take it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I am gone sir, and yet I think I'm w'ye.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Is the devil become a match-broker? what, who within there: what?
Annabell? what Friswood?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Here sir, I am here forsooth.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Are you so forsooth? but where's your mistress forsooth?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Listening is good sometimes; I heard their talk, and am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Where is your Mrs. I say?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: My Mrs. Annabell, forsooth, my young Mrs?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What other Mrs. hast thou but the devil's dam herself, your old Mrs.? and her I ask not for; good Mrs. Flibber De'jibb with the French fly-flap of your coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Is the old man mad trow?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I ask for Annabell.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Bless me! how do you look?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Where's Annabell I say? fetch her me quickly, lest I baste her out of your old whitleather hide.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
How youthful you are grown? she is not far to fetch sir; you know you commanded her to her chamber, and not to
appear in sight, till her debauched father was gone out o'the house.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: And is not he gone now forsooth? why call you her not?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I warrant he has told you some tale on her. That lewd knight, now he has undone himself by his unthrifty practises, begins to practise the undoing of his daughter too! is it not so forsooth? has he not put some wickedness into your head to set you against her?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I never knew thee a witch till now.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; I warrant he told you that your adversary Touchwood's son, and my mistress Annabell are in love league together.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Marry did he; and I will know the truth.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Darest thou laugh at me?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: No, no; but I laugh at the poor knight's officiousness, in hope of some great reward for the gullery that I put upon him: ha, ha, ha. Good sir a little patience, and I will tell! you. Ha, ha, ha — 'twas I that devised it for a lie, and told it him in hope that his telling of it to you, would provoke you to beat him out o'the house; for reporting a thing that had no probability or resemblance of a truth in it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Is it but so?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Sir I have been your creature this thirty years, down lying and uprising; (As you know) and you should believe me, you had me in my old mistress's days — —

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Ay, thou wast a handsome young wench then; now thou art old.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Yet not so wondrous old as to be sung in a ballet for't, or to have been able ere Adam wore beard to have crept into Eves bed, as I did into my mistresses. (Heaven pardon you, as I do with all my heart.)

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What in thy fooleries now?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Nor so old neither but you are content to make a sorry shift with me still; as your abilities will serve you —

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Come, come; thou art not old.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
Nay that's not it that troubles me: but that I, that served you before your daughter was born; I mean your daughter that
was mother to this daughter which now you have made your daughter; that I that saw the birth, the marriage, and the death of your daughter; and have had the governance of this her daughter ever since, till now she is marriageable; and have all this while been as pliant as a twig about you, and as true as the sheath to your steel as we say, that I should now be mistrusted to connive at an ill match for her, for whom my chiefest care has been from the cradle? there's the unkindness.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Enough, enough; Fid . I believe there is no such matter.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I thought you had known me —

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I do, I do; I prithee good Fid be quiet, it was a witty trick of thee to mock the poor knight withal: but a pox on him, he cost me a piece for his news; there's another for thee: but the best is he hath tied himself by it, never to trouble me more; I have that into my bargain.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: And you would tie me so too; would you?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Not so Fid, not so: but look to my girl, and thus far mark me. If ever I find that young Touchwood, the son of that miscreant, whose hatred I would not lose for all the good neighbourhood in the parish; if ever i say, he and your charge do but look upon one another, I'll turn her and you both out of doors: there i will be w'ye, look to't.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Agreed sir; agreed.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Look to't i say, i must abroad, my anger is not over yet: I would I could meet my adversary to scold it out; I shall be sick else.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: 'Twas well I overheard 'em, my young lovers had been spoiled else: had not I crossed the old angry man's purpose before he had met with the young timorous virgin, she had confessed all; and and all had been dashed now.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: How now Fris. is my grandfather gone out of door?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: If he were as safe out o'the world, it were well for you.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Nay say not so good Fris.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
Your unlucky father has destroyed all your hopes in Mr.
same Touchwood; in discovering your loves (What devil soever gave him the intelligence) and you must resolve never to see your sweet Sam again.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I must resolve to die first: o.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Ods pity! how now! why Mrs. why Annabell, why Mrs. Annabell; look up, look up I say, and you shall have him spite of your grandfather and all his works: what do you think I am an infidel, to take Mr. Samuels forty pieces? and a rundlet of old muskadine for nothing? come be well, and indeed you shall have him.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: O Sam, sweet Sam —

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: These lovesick maids seldom call upon other saints then their sweethearts; look up I say, your sweet Sam is coming.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Ha, where? where is he; why do you abuse me?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I say he will come presently; look up I say, forgive me! he comes indeed: my Mr. thought I was a witch, and I now suspect myself for one. O Mr. Samuel, how came you hither? here he is Mrs. what mean you to come now to undo her and yourself too? yet she had died and you had not come as you did. Why do you not look upon him and be well? get you gone, we are all undone if my Mr. come back and find you: speak to her quickly, then kiss her and part, you will be parted for ever else.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: How fares my love?

lg.l: Better then when I was in earthly being,
This bosom is a heaven to me; through death
I am arrived at bliss, most happily
To be so well revived thou madest me die.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I made you not die, as you will die, if you stand prattling till my Mr. return and take you: for Mr. Samuel, I must tell you Mr. Samuel, he knows all Mr. Samuel.

lg.l: My father knows as much, and that's the cause
Of my adventuring hither to instruct you
In a strange practice; here it is in writing,A paper.
'tis such a secret that I durst not trust
My tongue with the conveyance of't; nor have I
The confidence to hear it read: take it,
And in my absence join your best advices,
To give it life and action; 'tis rule ▪
Which (Though both hard and grievous to pursue)
Is all that can our hopes in love renew.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: What horrible thing must we do trow? pray let me see the paper, I hope there is no pistolling nor poisoning in it: though my old striker come short of the man he was to be with me, I would be loath to shorten his days with the danger of my neck; or making a bonfire in Smithfield: pray let me see the paper.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Not until my departure gentle Friswood.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Is there such horror in it, that you dare not stand the opening of the paper?

lg.l: Consider sweet our love is fever sick,
Even desperately to death;
And nothing but a desperate remedy
Is left us: for our bodily health, what sour
Unsavoury loathsome medicines we will take
But to remove an ague?
What sharp incisions, searings, and cruel corrosives
Are daily suffered, and what limbs dissevered
To keep a gangrene from the vital parts,
That a dismembred body yet may live!
We in like case must to preserve our love,
(If we dare say we love) adventure life,
Fame, honour, which are all but love's attendants
To maintain it.
I understand you, sweet,
And do before I read your strong injunction,
Resolve to give it faithful execution
Whate'er it be. I ha' got courage now,
And (With a constant boldness let me tell you)
You dare not lay that on me I'll not bear:
And love, predominant o'er all other passions,
Shall bear me out in't.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: O you have made me happy.

lg.l: As I live my master —
Kiss and away; whip quickly through the garden —
Run you up to your chamber; I'll see you out myself.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Thus let us breathe that till we meet again.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Whoop what d'ye mean?

lg.l: We leave for truce at raising of the siege,
Our interchanged hearts each others pledge.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Go fools, this sets you both but more on edge.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Farewell,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Sweet wife content thyself.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Yes content myself! shall I so? with what, you John Bopeep? you must be my husband, and I must content myself, must I? no sir, 'tis you that must content me, or 'tis your heart must smart for't.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: If you could be content with all that I have, or all that I can do, and expect no further, I then might hope to pacify you.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: All has not done it yet you see, nor have you yet found out the way. Five years practise one would think were sufficient, so long you have had me; and too long it is unless I had got a better name by't, to be accounted barren — — o me.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Now 'tis out; zonnes what would you have me do? where's the defect think you? is it not probable that you may be defective as well as I?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: That I may be defective! I defy thee, lubber; I defy thee and all that say so, thou fribling fumbler thou; I would some honest sufficient man might be judge betwixt us whether I be defective.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How now, always wrangling?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Defective quoth a —

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: What's the matter landlord?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Do I look like a thing defective?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Land-lady —

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: O fearful!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Mrs. Brittleware what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: You shall be judge sir Hugh, whether I be defective; you have lyen here sir Hugh these three years, have been our constant lodger off and on as we say; and can you think me defective?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: You will not be impudent?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Good ▪ Mr. Brittleware what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: The matter is sir she will be content with nothing.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: The best wife i'the world! and if you cannot afford her that to content her, you are a most hard-hearted husband.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: What nothing? would you wish him to afford me nothing to content me? I must have something to content me; and something he must find me, or I will make him look out for't.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Come, come, I know the quarrel; and I know you will never get a child by falling out.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Nor any way else so long as he is such a jealous beast as he is.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: O you must leave your jealousy Mr. Brittleware; that's a main hindrance

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I am not jealous I.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Not, and stare like a mad ox upon every man that looks upon me?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Fie upon him, is he such a beast, to be jealous of his own wife? if every man were so, it would spoil the getting of some children in a year.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: And denies me all things that I have a mind to.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: The best is ▪ the loss of your longings will not hurt you; unless you were with child.

lg.l: I must have my longings first; I am not every woman I,
I must have my longings before I can be with child I.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: You must not long for every strange thing you see or hear of then.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: As true as I live he fribbles with me sir Hugh; I do but now long for two or three idle things scarce worth the speaking of; and do you think he will grant me one of 'em?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: What may they be? he shall grant 'em.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: One of my longings is to have a couple of lusty able bodied men, to take me up, one before and another behind, as the new fashion is, and carry me in a man-litter into the great bed at Ware.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: There's one, and will you deny her this to hinder a child getting?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Then I do long to see the new ship, and to be on the top of Paul's steeple when it is new built, but that must not be yet; nor am I so unreasonable but I can stay the time: in the mean time I long to see a play, and above all plays, the knight of the burning — what d'ye call't.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: The knight of the burning pestle.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Pestle is it? I thought of another thing, but I would fain see it. They say there's a grocer's boy kills a giant in it, and another little boy that does a citizen's wife thy dainty — — but I would fain see their best actor do me; I would so put him to't, they should find another thing in handling of me I warrant 'em.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Heyday! so last frost she longed to ride on one of the dromedaries over the Thames, when great men were pleased to go over it a foot.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well, shall I make a convenient motion for you both?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Quickly sweet sir Hugh, I long for that before you name it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Have you this spring eaten any asparagus yet?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Why is that good for a woman that longs to be with child?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Of all the plants, herbs, roots, or fruits that grow, it is the most provocative, operative and effective.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Indeed sir Hugh?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
All your best (Especially your modern) herbalists conclude, that your asparagus is the only sweet stirrer that the
earth sends forth, beyond your wild carrots, corn-flag, or gladial. Your roots of standergrass, or of Satyrion boiled in goat's milk are held good; your clary or Horminum in divers ways good, and Dill (Especially boiled in oil) is also good: but none of these, nor saffron boiled in wine, your nuts of artichokes, rocket, or seeds of ash-tree (Which we call the kite keys) nor thousand such, though all are good, may stand up for perfection with asparagus.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Do you say so sir Hugh?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I have it from the opinion of most learned doctors, rare physicians, and one that dares call himself so.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: What doctor is he, a fool on horseback?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Doctor Thou-lord, you know him well enough.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Yes, we know doctor Thou-lord, though he knows none but lords and ladies, or their companions. And a fine conceited doctor he is, and as humorous I warrant ye; and will thou and thee the best lords that dares be acquainted with him: calls knights, Jack, will, and Tom familiarly; and great ladies, gills, and sluts too, and they cross him. And for his opinion's sake, and your good report sir Hugh, I will have sparagus every meal all the year long, or I'll make all fly for't; and do you look to't fribble, for it will be for your commodity as well as mine.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: And sure it is a rare commodity when a knight is become a broker for to cry it up so.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: And let me have some presently for my next meal, or you cannot imagine how sick I will be.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: But mistake not me ▪ nor the commodity we speak of Mrs. Brittleware; where would you have it? here in our own house? fie! the virtue of it is mortified, if it pass the threshold from the ground it grows on. No, you must thither, to the garden of delight, where you may have it dressed and eaten in the due kind; and there it is so provocative, and so quick in the hot operation, that none dare eat it, but those that carry their coolers with 'em, presently to delay, or take off the delightful fury it fills 'em with.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Is there conveniency for that too?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
Yes, yes; the house affords you as convenient couches to retire to, as the garden has beds for the precious plants to
grow in: that makes the place a palace of pleasure, and daily resorted and filled with lords and knights, and their ladies; gentlemen and gallants with their mistresses —

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: But do not honest men go thither with their wives too?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: None other; some to their own costs, and some at other men's.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Why do we not go then? or what stay we for, can you tell fumbler?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Nay Mrs. Brittleware, not so suddenly; towards the evening will be the fittest season of the day: meanwhile go in and fit yourself for the walk, your husband and I are first for another business.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Noble knight I thank you, I hope my next longing shall be to bespeak you for a godfather.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You shall not long long for that.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: I take your noble word.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: She's gone, and now sir Hugh let me tell you, you have not dealt well with me, to put this fagary into her foolish fancy.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Wilt thou be an ass now? do not I know how to fetch it out on her again think'st thou? she shall not go, and yet be contented too.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Ay you tell me so

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Why thou wilt not be jealous of me now, that has lain in thy house these three years, wilt thou? nor think me so foolish to provoke thee with an injury; that knowest me and my ways so well.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I know something by your worship worth the price of a new pillory.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Why so then; and will I wrong thee Jack think'st thou, ha? no nor mistrust thee neither: for though thou art a jealous coxcomb over thy wife, and she a touchy thing under thee, yet thou and I Jack have been always confident of each other, and have wrought friendly and closely together, as ever subtle and his lungs did; and shared the profit betwixt us, han't we Jack: ha?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I think we have; and that you have some new device, some stratagem in hand now. Uds me, I now remember, is the party come to town?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
Yes; and my spring has seized him upon the way: and
here I expect him instantly.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: And will he be made a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: That's his ambition Jack; and though you now keep a china-shop, and deal in brittle commodities (Pots, glasses, purslane dishes, and more trinkets than an antiquaries study is furnished withal) you must not forget your old trade of barber surgeon, 'tis that must stead us now in our new project.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I warrant you, is he a trim youth?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: We must make him one Jack, 'tis such a squab as thou never sawest; such a lump, we may make what we will of him.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Then sure we will make money of him.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well said Jack, spring has writ me here his full description.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Slid he's come already: now Mr. spring?

sp.speaker: Spri.
sp.p: I come to present a gentleman to you sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How a gentleman? will you abuse me?

sp.speaker: Spri.
sp.p: He finds your defect already; but be bold sir, he desires to be a gentleman sir; and (Though he be but course mettle, yet) he has that about him which with your help may quickly make him a clear gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I have four hundred pounds sir; and I brought it up to town on purpose to make myself a clear gentleman of it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: It was well brought up; it appears also that you have had some breeding, though but a yeoman's son.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I have a little learning sir, and a little wit, though last night I met with some upon the way at hammersmith that had more: yet I had enough to perceive I was cheated of a matter of seven pound (Almost all the odd money I had about me) at my card afore thy card; a pox take the whole pack on 'em. 'sdaggers if ever man that had but a mind to be a gentleman was so noddy pooped! o how I could chafe to think on't.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: O but you must not, it becomes not the temper of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: So you told me; then I thank you friend.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Your small acquaintance sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I have had more acquaintance where I have found less love, and I thank you again good small acquaintance: you told me indeed it became not a gentleman to cry for losing his money; and I told you then, that I should, or would be a gentleman: whereupon small acquaintance (Because I was resolved to play no more) you advised me to give over; and you told me you would upon our coming to the city, here bring me to a knight, that was a gentleman-maker, whom I conceive this to be, and here am I, and here's my four hundred pound, which my man has here drawn up to town, and here I mean to quarter it.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: But I will see what pennyworths you bargain for first, by your mastership's leave.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Drawn and quartered! you have a wit sir, I find that already.

sp.speaker: Hoy,
sp.p: Yes sir, I have a down right country wit, and was counted a pretty spark at home. Did you never hear of little Tim of Tanton? But I now mean to have a finical city wit, and a superfinical court wit too, before I see mine uncle.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You may sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: And be able to jest and jeer among men of judgement: I have a many small jests, petty johns, as I call 'em: but I will have a clubbing wit, and a drinking wit; and be able to hold play with the great poets I: and with dry jests to maul the mallipart'st lesser ones (That hold themselves better than the biggest) out o'the pit of wit I, before I see mine uncle.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You may have all sir, if you quarter your four hundred pound discreetly: but who is your uncle I pray?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: For that you shall pardon me, till I am a gentleman: but I assure you he is a great gentleman in the city here; and I neither must nor dare see him, till I am one at least: and I will tell you presently how I mean to quarter my money.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: They'll quarter that and you too, if I zee not the better to the matter.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Dost thou know the uncle he speaks of?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: No, nor cannot learn who it is for my life.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Some great man sure that's ashamed of his kindred: perhaps some suburb justice, that sits o'the skirts o'the city, and lives by't.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well said Jack.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Look you sir, thus had I cast it: small acquaintance prey do you note it too: I love your advice, that at first sight of me (Which was but last night) could relieve me from cheaters.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: From some of his own companions to cheat, you more himself.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: The first hundred pound to be for the making of me a gentleman: the second hundred shall be for apparel.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: He speaks half like a gentleman already.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Right, there's half disposed of.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: The third hundred I'll spend in pleasure: hark small acquaintance, we'll have wenches.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: What wants he of a gentleman, and go no further, but save the last hundred.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: O small acquaintance, that must walk too: but all for profit to support my gentility hereafter.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I will be cheated of it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Nor in gross, but by retail, to try men's several wits, and so learn to shift for myself in time and need be.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Do you hear this?

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: There's a plot now!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I protest I admire him: i never found like craft in a yeoman's son before.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: No words on't i beseech you sir; nor name that foolish word yeoman's son any more: i came to change my copy, and write gentleman: and to go the nighest way to work, my small acquaintance here tells me, to go by the heralds is the farthest way about.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well sir, we will take the speediest course for you that may be possible.

lg.l: The season of the year serves most aptly too,
Both for purging and bleeding:
Give your name into this book sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Timothy Hoyden, sir.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Timothy Hoyden.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: But must i bleed sir?

lg.l: Yes, you must bleed: your father's blood must out,
he was but a yeoman, was he?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: As rank a clown, none dispraised, as any in Somersetshire .

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: His foul rank blood of bacon and peas-porridge must out of you to the last dram.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: You will leave me none in my body then, I shall bleed to death, and you go that way to work.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Fear nothing sir: your blood shall be taken out by degrees, and your veins replenished with pure blood still, as you lose the puddle.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: How must that be done?

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: I that ich I would hear.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I commend you that you seek reason: it must be done by meats and drinks of costly price; muscadel caudles, jellies, and cock-broths. You shall eat nothing but shrimp porridge for a fortnight; and now and then a pheasant's egg sopped with a peacock's feather. I that must be the diet.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Delicate!

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: This stands to reason indeed.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Then at your going abroad, the first air you take shall be of the asparagus garden, and you shall feed plentifully of that.

sp.speaker: Hoy
sp.p: Of the air do you mean?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: No of th'asparagus. And that with a Concoction of goat's milk, shall set you an end, and your blood as high as any gentleman's lineally descended from the loins of King Cadwalader.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Excellent, I like all excellently well, but this bleeding. I could never endure the sight of blood.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: That shows the malignant baseness of your father's blood within you ▪

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I was bewitched I think before I was begotten, to have a clown to my father: yet sit my mother said she was a gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Said? What will not women say?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p:
Nay, small acquaintance, she professed it upon her deathbed to the curate and divers others, that she was sister to a gentleman here in this city; and commanded me in her will, and upon her blessing, first to make myself a gentleman of good fashion,
and then to go to the gentleman my uncle.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: What gentleman is that?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I must not, nor I won't tell you that, till I am a gentleman myself: would you ha' me wrong the will of the dead? Small acquaintance, I will rather die a clown as I am first.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Be content sir; here's half a labour saved; you shall bleed but of one side: the father's side only.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Say you so?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: The mother vain shall not be pricked.

lg.l: I thank you sir:
I would 'twere done once.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: But when this is done, and your new blood infused into you, you shall most easily learn the manners and behaviour.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: The look, the garb, the congee —

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: And all the compliments of an absolute gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: O brave!

lg.l: For which you shall have best instructions;
You'll run a chargeable course in't, that I'll tell you:
And may yet if you please retain your money;
Cross your mother's will and die a clown.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: By no means sir.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: I begin to believe honestly of the knight.

sp.speaker: Mon
sp.p: Do you note this skin of his here?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Skin, 'tis a hide sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: 'Tis somewhat thick and foul indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: He must have a bath, and that will be more charge.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: 'Tis pity he should be flayed.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I thank you small acquaintance; pray let me have a bath, whate'er it cost me, rather than flay me.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well sir, this house shall be your lodging, and this the Mr. of it, an excellent chirurgeon, and expert in these affairs, shall be your attendant.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: My man may attend me too, may he not?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Yes, by all means, and see the laying out of your money.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: I like that best: sure they are honest men.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Is that your man? what does he wear a coulter by his side?

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p:
No sir, my name is coulter; I myself am a coulter.
and this is but my hanger on, as I am my masters.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Thou mayst make a country gentleman in time, I see that by thy wit.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: All my friends will be glad on't.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Come gentlemen, I'll lead you the way.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: But how can you assure me gentlemen that this is true?

lg.l: We saw't not acted sir, nor had reported it,
But on those terms of honour you have sworn to;
In which you are engaged first to forgive
Your son: then never to reveal to friend,
Or foe, the knowledge of the fact.
You cannot now but receive
Your son into your favour, that did urge him
To do some outrage, some villainous shame or mischief
Upon that family as he would shun your curse.
This is a mischief with a witness to it:
He has done it home it seems.
Sir, can a son
Do his father's will too fully?
You may be pleased to call him. Exit Wat.
I would now put on anger, but I fear
My inward joy's too great, to be dissembled:
Now for a rigid brow that might enable
A man to stand competitor for the seat
Of austere justice — are you come to boastEnter Sam, Wat.
The bravery of your fact, with a dissembled
Show of obedience; as if you had merited
Forgiveness and a blessing; when my shame
For thy lewd action makes me turn and hide
My face — for fear my laughter be descried.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Pray turn not from him sir.

lg.l: I have heard sir of your workmanship; but may
A man receive it on your word for truth?
It is too true, unless you please in mercy
to pardon, and preserve me from the rigour
Of justice, and the sharper censure
That I shall suffer in all good opinion.
I mean you shall out o'the noise on't presently:
So — there's a hundred pieces, get you gone;
Provide you for a journey into France,
Bear yourself well, and look you come not home
A verier coxcomb than you went abroad:
Pray wear no falling bands and cuffs above
The price of suits and cloaks, lest you become
The better half undone in about at buffets.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I hope you shall hear well of me.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Pray bless me sir.

lg.l: My blessing be upon thee,
Go get thee gone, my tenderness will show
Itself too womanish else.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Goodness of nature.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: We'll help to set you forward.

lg.l: Thank ye gentlemen:
Be but my son, thou shalt not want a father,
Though somebody must seek one: ha, ha, ha —
I'd give another hundred pieces now
With all my heart, that I might be untongue-tied,
And triumph o'er my adversary now,
And dash this business in his angry teeth:
Strike strikers teeth out with his own abuse:
Perhaps he knows't already, if he does;
I may take notice, and make bold to jeer him:
This is his usual walk.
I was too blame
To give it so much credit at the first,
As to be troubled at it.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: 'Tis the rascal.

lg.l: That he, the son of my despite and scorn,
should gain of fate a lot to see my niece,
Much less a face to ask her for his wife.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Perhaps he's casting of his will.

lg.l: Yet the vexation that I was but told so,
Lies gnawing in my stomach, that until
I vomit it upon that dunghill wretch;
I cannot eat nor sleep to do me good.
And I thank chance he's here.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: He comes, and so have at him.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hum, hum, hum, humh.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And ha, ha, ha to thee old puppy.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Sirrah, sirrah, how dar'st thou keep a son that dares but look upon my niece? there I am wi'ye sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Sirrah, and sirrah to thy withered jaws, and down that wrinkled throat of thine: how dar'st thou think a son of mine dares for displeasing me, look but with foul contempt upon thy loathed issue?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Impudent villain, I have heard he has seen her.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Has he but seen her? ha, ha, ha, I fear I shall out with it: I would not be forsworn: I'll keep't in if I can.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Yes malapert Jack, I have heard that he has seen her, but better hadst thou pissed him 'gainst the wall, than he presume to love her: and there I am wi'ye sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Hast thou but heard he has seen her: I tell thee thou old booby thou; if he had seen, felt, heard, and understood her: nay had he got her with child, and then left her, he were my son, and I would cherish him.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Dar'st thou speak so, thou old reprobate.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Thou dost not hear me say it is so, though i could wish it were with all my heart, because I think it would break thine.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hugh, hugh, hugh.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I hope I shall keep it within the compass of mine oath; yet there was a touch for him.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: O thou hellbred rascal thou; hugh, hugh,

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: So, so, up with it, lungs, lights, liver, and all: choke up in a churl's name.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hugh, hugh.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I have put him into these fits forty times at least, and not without hope it will throttle him at last — — if you do break a gut, or a rib or two, with straining, a rope will be your only remedy: and so I leave you: by the way you have not heard me say that I know any thing by your niece: but what I know I'll keep to myself.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: And hang thyself, I care not what thou knowest, yet thus far take me wi'ye sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Not a step, unless I were sure I were going to the devil, huh, huh: no sir, you shall not trip me: you shall not fetch it out of me: tush, my son's my son, and keep your niece to yourself, huh, and if she has any thing of his you may keep that too huh; and so choke up again with all my heart, and much good do it you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Huh, huh — hum! so he's gone, the villain's gone in hope that he has killed me, when my comfort is he has recovered me:

lg.l: I was heartsick with a conceit which lay so mingled with my
Phlegm that I had perished, if I had not broke it, and made me
Spit it out; hemh, 'tis gone, and I'll home merrily.
I would not that he should know the good he has done me
For half my estate; nor would I be at peace with him
To save it all: his malice works upon me,
Passed all the drugs and all the doctors counsels,
That ere I coped with: he has been my vexation
These thirty years; nor have I had another
Ere since my wife died; if the rascal knew't,
He would be friends, and I were instantly
But a dead man, I could not get another
To anger me so handsomely.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: You are welcome home sir.

lg.l: And merrily too Fid. Hemh light at heart,
I met with my physician, dog-leech, Touchwood;
And cleared my stomach, and now I am light at heart.
And thou shalt hear on't Fid anon perhaps.
You are the better able than to hear
and bear what I must tell you.
Where's my niece?
How does she , ha?
As well as a young woman
In her case may do sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Ha! how's that?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: 'Twill out, and I as fit to tell't you as another.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Out with it then.

lg.l: 'Tis true, I faced you down there was no league
Between young Touchwood, and your niece, in hope
To turn her heart from him before the knowledge
Of any thing that passed should be a grief to you:
But since I have discovered 'tis too late;
And she can be fit bride for no man else.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: He has not lain with her, has he?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: You speak as just as Gorman's lips.

lg.l: I hope he has not lipped her so:
Prithee what canst thou mean?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Sir, if you think
The knowledge of a truth of this sad nature
May prejudice your health, by drawing a choleric fit into you, you were best to send for your physician, your dog-leech Touchwood, as you called him, to break your bed of phlegm, by laughing at you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What dost thou mean now, I have asked thee twice.

lg.l: I say young Touchwood has touched, and clapped your niece;
And (Which is worse) with scorn and foul disdain
Has left and quite forsaken; and is gone:
(They say) sent by his father to travail.
'Twas this the villain hammered on today,
When he spoke mystically, doubtful words,
Reflecting on this mischievous sense: hell, hell, hell.
'Twere good you would forsake the thought of hell sir,
And think upon some timely course to save
Her credit, and the honour of your house by marriage.
You counsel very well;
But were you privy in their love's affair?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Indeed I knew too much on't: think of a course good sir.

lg.l: I know no course for her and you but one,
Young whore and bawd, and that is instantly
To pack you out of doors to seek your living,
And there I will be wi'ye.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Sir that you must not.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Sprecious dost thou must me in mine own house?

lg.l: In your own house sir, kill us if you please,
And take the sin upon you; but out of it
You must not dare to thrust us with your shame:
Which I will so divulge, as you shall find
Your house to be no sanctuary for yourself;
And there I'll be with you ▪

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: This is lusty.

lg.l: Consider wisely that I know you sir,
And can make foul relation of some passages
That you will shame to hear.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hold your peace.

lg.l: Remember sir, near thirty years ago,
You had a sister, whose great marriage portion
Was in your hands: good gentlewoman, she
Unfortunately loving a false squire,
Just as your niece hath now, did get a clap:
You know sir what I mean.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You'll hold your peace?

lg.l: I'll speak it though I die for't; better here
Than in a worse place: so clapped I say she was,
I know not yet by whom you do, and bear
An inward grudge against somebody to this hour for't.
But to my story, good gentlewoman she
Was by your most unbrotherly cruel usage
Thrust out a doors, as now you threaten us:
And miserably big-bellied as she was
Leaving her most unjustly detained her portion
In your false hands, forsook you and the town,
To fly the air, where her disgrace was spread:
Some jewels and some gold she had concealed:
But to what part o'th' world she took we know not,
Nor did you ever care, but wished her out on't,
by any desperate end, after her flight
From portion, blood and name; and so perhaps
Immediately she was: for which, this judgement
Is justly fallen upon you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Yet hold thy peace.

lg.l: Neither by threats, nor bribes, nor all persuasion,
Until you take your niece into your care:
What will the world say when it hears this story
Of your own natural sister, and your cruelty,
When you shall second it with your niece's shame?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I never was so mated, so astonished.

lg.l: Nay, more than this, old striker, I'll impeach
You for foul incontinence; and shaking your
Old bullion trunks over my trucklebed.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Thou art not desperate! wilt thou shame thyself?

lg.l: I value neither shame, nor name, nor fame;
And wealth I have none to lose; you have enough
To pay for all I take it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: O I am sick.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Be of good cheer, I'll send for your physician.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Sick, sick at heart; let me be had to bed.

lg.l: I hope I have laid the heat of his severity,
So sometimes great offences pass for none,
When severe judges dare not hear their own.

div.head: Scene 1.
div.stage: Enter Gardner, and Martha his wife.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p:
Pray let's agree upon't good wife, you are my wife I take it, and I should have the command, yet I entreat,
and am content you see.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: And so would any man I think that has such a help and comings in by his wife as you have: 'tis not your dirty sparagus, your artichokes, your carps, your tulips, your strawberries, can bring you in five hundred pound a year, if my helping hand, and brain too were not in the business?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: Let us agree upon't: and two or three years toil more, while our trade is in request and fashion, will make us purchasers. I had once a hope to have bought this manor of Marshland for the resemblance it has to the low country soil you came from, to ha' made you a Bankside lady. We may in time be somewhat. But what did you take yesterday Mat in all, what had you, ha?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Poor piddling doings; some four and twenty pound.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: What did the rich old merchant spend upon the poor young gentleman's wife in the yellow bedchamber?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: But eight and twenty shillings, and kept the room almost two hours, I had no more of him.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: And what the knight with the broken citizens wife (That goes so lady like) in the blue bedchamber.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Almost four pound.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: That was pretty well for two.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: But her husband, and a couple of serving-men had a dish of sparagus, and three bottles of wine, besides the broken meat into one o'the arbours.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: Every thing would live Mat: but here will be great courtiers and ladies today you say.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Yes they sent last night to bespeak a ten pound dinner, but I half fear their coming will keep out some of our more constant, and more profitable customers.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: 'Twill make them the more eager to come another time then Mat. Have they paid their reckoning in the parlour?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Yes, but hutchingly, and are now going away.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: O here they are going.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I protest Mr. Gardner your wife is too dear: sixteen shillings for a dish of sparagus, two bottles of wine, and a little sugar, I wonder how you can reckon it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: That was your reckoning in all sir; we make no account of particulars, but all to mall, as they do in the Netherlands.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Your Dutch account Mrs. is too high for us to trouble you any more.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: That's as you please sir, a fair day after you:
Who would be troubled with such pinching guests?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis good to misreckon such to be rid of 'em.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: They are e'en as welcome as the knight that comes hither alone always, and walks about the garden here half a day together, to feed upon lady's looks, as they pass to and fro; the peeping knight, whát do you call him?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: O sir Arnold cautious.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You may call him cautious, I never saw five shillings of his money yet.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: No, he comes but to feed his eye, as you say, with leering at good faces, and peeping at pretty insteps.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Sir Hugh-money-lacke, our gather-guest as we call him, sends us no such dull customers: oh that good gentleman I never did any tavern, inn, or new ordinary give tribute to a more deserving gentleman — o here come gallants.

div.head: Act 3. Scene 3.
div.stage: Enter Gilbert, Wat, and same (Disguised) to them.
div.p: Three, and never a woman! strange! these are not the courtiers we look for.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: This is his daily haunt: I warrant thee we find him.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: And it shall take, never fear it Sam.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: By your leave Mr. and Mrs. or rather lord and lady of the new plantation here.

sp.speaker: Wat
sp.p: Nay prince and Princess of the province of asparagus.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: The island of two acres here, more profitable than twice two thousand in the fens, till the drainers have done there.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You are pleasant gentlemen: what is your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Saw you sir Arnold cautious here today?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Not yet sir.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Have you a room i' your house for us?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Have you any more company to come to you?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yes, we expect some gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Gentlemen did you say?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Yes indeed gentlemen, no gentlewomen I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Intruth sir all the rooms within are gone.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: What they are not gone abroad, are they?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You are always pleasant sir: I mean they are all taken up.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: There are some taken up in 'em, is't not so?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Still you are pleasant sir: they are indeed bespoken for great courtiers, and ladies that are to dine here.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: If you will bestow yourselves in the garden, and make choice of your arbour: you shall have the best cheer the house can afford ye, and you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Be it so then; let's walk about gentlemen. Pray send us some wine.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: And a dish of your sparagus.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You shall have it gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Did you note the wit o'the woman?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Ay, because we had no wenches we must have no chamber-room, for fear she disappoint some that may bring 'em.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: She spoke of great courtiers and ladies that are to come.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Some good stuff perhaps.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Why I assure you, right noble, and right virtuous persons, and of both sexes do frequent the place.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: And I assure you, as ignoble and vicious do pester it too much; and these that respect profit merely have not the wit, and less the virtue to distinguish betwixt the best and the worst, but by their purses.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: 'Tis enough for them to weed their garden, not their guests: oh here comes our collation.

div.head: Act 3. Scene 4.
div.stage: Enter two boys, they cover a table, two bottles of wine, dishes of sugar, and a dish of sparagus.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And what's the price of this feast boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Playst ill Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: What art thou a Frenchman?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No, I took you for one sir, to bargain for your meat before you eat it, that is not the generous English fashion, you shall know anon sir.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Go get you gone with your wit, and tell your prodigal fools so.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Go, we'll call when we want attendance.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Sam you are too sad; let not your disguise alter you with us: come here's a health to the Hans in Kelder, and the mother of the boy, if it prove so.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I'll pledge it.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: We want sir Hugh Money-lack here to discourse the virtues of this precious plant asparagus, and what wonders it hath wrought in Burgundy, Almaino, Italy, and Languedoc before the herborists had found the skill to plant it here.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What's he to whom we seek?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Who mine uncle, sir Arnold cautious; he'll come, never doubt him; he seldom misses a day to pry and pier upon the beauties that come to walk here.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: 'Tis such a knightling, I'll but give ye his character, and and he comes I warrant thee ▪ he is an infinite admirer of beauty, and dares not touch a woman: he is aged about fifty, and a ▪ bachelor: he defies wed lock, because he thinks there is not a maiden - head in any marriageable beauty to be found among women.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Yet you say he is an admirer and hunter after the sight of beauty.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: He gets a crick in his neck oft-times with squinting up at windows and balconies; and as he walks the streets, he peeps on both sides at fair breasts and faces, as he were seeking birds-nests; and follows pretty feet and insteps like a hare tracker.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: This is still mine uncle.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And when he sees a coach of ladies about to alight, he makes a stand, in hope to see a delicate leg slip through a laced smock, which if he chance to discover he drivels.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Well, how your plot may hold to my purpose I cannot see: he is the unlikeliest man to have a wench put upon that you can mention.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I grant the attempt is hard, but the higher will be the achievement: trust my experience Sam: for as in every instrument are all tunes to him that has the skill to find out the stops, so in every man there are all humours to him that can find their faussets, and draw 'em out to his purpose.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Fear not the plot, as we have cast it, nor the performance in the comedy, though against mine own natural uncle.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Thy unnatural uncle thou wouldst say; he never did thee good in's life: act but thine own part, and be not out Sam, and fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: He's somewhat too young to act a roarer: but what lads have we seen pass for soldiers?

div.head: Act 3. Scene 5.
div.stage: Enter three courtiers and ladies: cautious aloof.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: O here come the great guests.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And these are noble ones indeed; these are courtiers clinquant, and no counterfeit stuff upon 'em: I know 'em all, every lady with her own husband too: what a virtuous 'Honest age is this: and see if thine uncle be not at his old game, bopeep i'the tail of'em . He shall follow 'em no further: sir Arnold cautious, noble knight you are well encountered.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Good master gold wire, do you know these ladies; or be they ladies, ha?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Yes, and noble ones, the three graces of the court, the lady stately, the lady handsome, and the lady peerless, do not you know 'em?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: No not I.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: How the slave twitters; you look not up at greatness, you mind too much the worldly things that are beneath you: if you had such a lady under you, (Of your own I mean) you would mind her.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: O fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Look no more after 'em, they are gone: besides they are virtuous, and too too great for you: when will you get a convenient wife of your own, to work out the dry itch of a stale bachelor?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Go, go, you are a wag, I itch not that way.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Will you go this way with me then, and hear what I will say to you?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: With all my heart, I am free from business.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: You have a nephew, whose sister I married, a virtuous wife she is, and I love him the better for't; he is a younger brother, and born to no great fortune: now you are very rich, a bachelor, and therefore I think child less —

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Introth Mr. Gold-wire you must pardon me, I may not stay with you: I had almost forgotten a most important business.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: E'en now he had none.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Nay good sir Arnold cautious, you know not what I'll say.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I say he is an unthrift, a squanderer, and must not expect supplies from me.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: He does not, shall not, not to the value of a token: pray stay, and hear me sir; 'tis no ill air to stay in.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I withal my heart good Mr. Gold-wire; I like the air well, and your motion hitherto.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Will you be pleased to do your kinsman the favour to further him in a match; I mean an honest lawful marriage match — but with your countenance, and a good word at most.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: The most unthankful office in the world: pray use some other friend in't: indeed I stay too long.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Hear but who it is that he loves, how likely he is to obtain, what abundant profit the match may bring him, and the desperate undoing danger he falls into if he be not matched, and then do your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p:
Why what new danger is he towards, more than the old
ill company he was wont to keep?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: O sir, he is now in league with a companion more dreadful than 'em all, a fellow that is in part a poet, and in part a soldier.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Bounce, bounce.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: You have hit upon his name: his name is Bounce, do you know him sir?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Not I, nor desire acquaintance with either of his qualities.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: He is a gentleman sir, that has been upon some unfortunate late services, that have not answered his merit.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: And now he is come home to right himself, by writing his own meritorious acts, is he?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Good introth, I wish you would see 'em, to come over 'em with a jeer or two; I know you are good at it: they are in an arbour here close by, drinking to their muses, and glorifying one another for either's excellency in the art most poetically.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Glorify do you say? I have heard poets the most envious detractors of one another of all creatures, next to the very beggars.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Abroad perhaps and asunder, but together there's no such amity: you never saw 'em drink; pray see 'em sir, it may take your nephew off of his ningle, who hath infected him with poetry already: and twenty to one, if he fail in the match, which I was about to mention; he will win him away to the wars too, and then he may be lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Good Mr. Gold-wire go you to your company, I am not a man of reckoning amongst such; besides, I seldom drink betwixt meals.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: At his own cost he means.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I commend your temper: you shall not be in the reckoning; but I beseech you let me prevail with you: see, we are upon hem: save you gentlemen: I have brought you a noble friend, your uncle; I know he is welcome to you brother Wat; and you I am sure will make him so Mr. bounce: when you shall hear he is an admirer of poetry and war.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p:
Even afar off I assure ye: I never durst approach near
the fury of either of the fiery qualities.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: It is your modesty, not fear that keeps you at distance I imagine.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Poet's may imagine any thing: imagination is their wealth, some of 'em would be but poor else: are you turned poet nephew?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: For my private recreation sir.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: What by writing verses to win some mistresses to your private recreation: mean you so?

lg.l: You dare not sir blaspheme the virtuous use
Of sacred poetry, nor the fame traduce
Of poets, who not alone immortal be,
But can give others immortality.
Poets that can men into stars translate,
And hurl men down under the feet of fate:
'Twas not Achilles sword, but Homer's pen,
That made brave Hector die the best of men:
And if that powerful Homer likewise would,
Helen had been a hag, and Troy had stood.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Well said poet, thou tumblest out old ends as well as the best of 'em.

lg.l: Poets they are the life and death of things,
Queens give them honour, for the greatest Kings
Have been their subjects.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Enough, enough; you are the first good poet that e'er I saw wear so good a countenance: leave it, I would not have a gentleman meddle with poetry for spoiling of his face: you seldom see a poet look out at a good visnomy.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Think you so sir?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Yes, and that it is a poetical policy, where the face is naturally good without spot or blemish, to deface it by drinking, or wenching, to get a name by't.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A death deserving scandal.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Hold, hold.

div.stage: They scuffle, and what throws. Sam, and offers to stab him. Gil. holds his dagger.

lg.l: Thy malice, and thy ignorance
Have doomed thee.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Gentlemen what mean ye?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: My blood must not endure it.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: You have wronged us all, and me the most.

lg.l: The wrong is chiefly mine; yet you add to it
By hindering my just vengeance.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I'll find a time to right you, or myself.

lg.l: My next sight of thee is thy death:
I fear you are hurt sir; are you, pray sir tell me?
Let me first admire thy goodness and thy pity:
My own true natural nephew.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Now it works.

lg.l: I now consider, and will answer thee
In a full measure of true gratitude.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: But good sir are you not hurt? if you bleed, I bleed with you.

lg.l: O sincere nephew, good boy I am not hurt,
Nor can I think of hurt, my thoughts are bent
Upon thy good; you were speaking of a choice sir,
My nephew would be matched to, let me know the party.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Will you sir stand his friend?

lg.l: Let me but know the party and her friend,
And instantly about it.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: He is catched.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: How am I bound to you!

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Nephew I am yet bound to thee, and shall not rest till I am disengaged by doing this office for thee: what is she, let me know?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Sir, as we walk you shall know all: I'll pay the reckoning within as we pass.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: But by the way nephew, I must bind you from poetry.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: For a wife you shall sir.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Poetry, though it be of a quite contrary nature, is as pretty a jewel as plain dealing, but they that use it forget the proverb.

lg.l: Come madams, now if you please after your garden feast,
To exercise your numerous feet, and tread
A curious knot upon this grassy square;
you shall fresh vigour add unto the spring,
And double the increase, sweetness and beauty
Of every plant and flower throughout the garden.
If I thought so my lord, we would not do
Such precious work for nothing; we would be
Much better huswives, and compound for shares
O'th' gardener's profit.
Or at least hedge in
Our sparagus dinner reckoning.
I commend your worldly providence:
Madam, such good ladies will never dance
Away their husbands lands.

sp.speaker: 1 courtier
sp.p: But madams will ye dance?

lg.l: Not to improve the garden good my lord,
