A little for digestion if you please.

sp.speaker: 1 courtier
sp.p: Music, play.

lg.l: You have done nobly ladies, and much honoured
This piece of earth here, with your graceful footing.

sp.speaker: 1 la.
sp.p: By your fair imitation, good my lords.

lg.l: May the example of our harmless mirth
And civil recreation purge the place
Of all foul purposes.
'Tis an honest wish:
But wishes weed no gardens; hither come
Some wicked ones they say.
We seek not to abridge their privilege;
Nor can their ill hurt us; we are safe.

sp.speaker: 1 la.
sp.p: But let us walk, the time of day calls hence.

sp.speaker: 1 courtier
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You are now welcome to th' asparagus garden landlady.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: I have been long a coming for all my longings: but now I hope I shall have my belly full on't.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: That you shall, fear not.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Would I were at it once.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well, because she desires to be private, go in with your wife Mr. Brittleware, take a room, call for a feast, and satisfy your wife, and bid the Mrs: of the house to provide for us.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: And how do you feel yourself Mr. Hoyden after your bleeding, purging, and bathing, the killing of your gross humours by your spare diet, and your new infusion of pure blood, by your quaint feeding on delicate meats and drinks? how do you feel yourself?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Marry I feel that I am hungry, and that my shrimped yet and sippings have almost famished me, and my purse too; slid I dare be sworn, as I am almost a gentleman, that every bit and every spoonful that I have swallowed these ten days, has cost me ten shillings at least.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Is it possible that you can consider this, and be almost a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Small acquaintance I do not lie to you: truth's truth, as well in a gentleman as a beggar, for I am both almost, and perhaps not the first that can write so.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Do you note how his wit rises?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: There's one of my hundred pounds gone that way, all but these twelve pieces.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: You see now what a fine hand you have made of your money, since you got it out of my clutches.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Then there's my apparel, a hundred pound went all in three suits, of which this is the best.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: But what do you think of your wit hundred pound?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Marry I think that was the best laid out: for by it I have got wit enough to know that I was as clearly cozened of it as heart can wish: of my soul and conscience, and as I am almost a gentleman, and a man had come to London for nothing else but to be cheated, he could not be more roundlier rid of his money.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
Well sir, if you repine at your expenses now, that you want nothing but your bellyful of sparagus to finish my work of a gentleman in you; I will, if you please, in lieu of that stuff up your paunch with bacon and bag-pudding and put you
back again as absolute a clown as ever you came from plough.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: I would he're come to that once.

sp.speaker: Sprin.
sp.p: Take heed how you cross him.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Nay pray sir be not angry, (Though to the shame of a gentleman I say it) my teeth do e'en water at the name of the sweet country dish you spoke of (Bacon and bag-pudding) yet I will forbear it: but you say I shall fill my belly with this new Daintrill that you spoke of; these sparowbills, what do you call 'em.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You shall have your belly full.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Top full I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Coul
sp.p: Humh —

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You shall: but I must tell you, I must ha' you turn away this grumbling clown that follows you: he is as dangerous about you, as your father's blood was within you, to cross and hinder your gentility.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: True, you said you would help me to a boy no bigger than a monkey.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: And you shall have him, a pretty little knave, you may put him in your pocket.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: Yes wiss, to pick's money out if he had it; shortly 'twill come to that bevore't be long.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Coulter you must to the plough again; you are too heavy a clog at the heels of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: I with all my heart, and I con you thanks too.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: The clown, my father's heir, will be glad of you.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Have you an elder brother?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: You do not hear me say he is my brother; but the clown my father had a former son, by a former wife, that was no gentlewoman as my mother was, and he is a clown all over, and incurable, even get you to him, like to like will agree well: here's a crown for you, 'twill carry you a foot to Tanton; and so get you gone like a clown as you are.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: 'Tis well you allow me some mon ey yet: we shall have you beg all the way home shortly, when your cheaters have done we 'Ye.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How villain!

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Why do you not correct him sir?

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: Nay why do not you, he dares not? though he could spare his clown blood, he dares not venture his gentleman blood so, nor you yours, 'tis all too fine I doubt; therefore keep it, and make much on't: I would be ▪ loathe a jail should stay my journey, or by my Cursen soul I would see, what colour the best on't were before I go. But if I don't your errand to your brother, and tellen how you do vlout 'em behind's back, then say Cut's a cur: and so a vart vor a varewell to the proudest o'ye; and if you be an angered, take't in your angry teeth.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Mon. ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: What a rude rascal 'tis? you are happy that he is gone.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: And so am I, he hindered half my work; seven years time is too little to make a gentleman of one that can suffer such a clown within seven mile of him.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Would he were beyond Brainford on his way then by this time for me. But you forget the way you were in; you said you would fill my belly; and then fall to practise fine compliments and congees to make me a perfect gentleman, and fit to see mine unknown uncle.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: All shall be done.

div.head: Act 3. Scene 8.
div.stage: Enter Brittleware and Rebecca to them.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: See if my surgeon and his wife have not filled themselves, and come wiping their lips already.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: So shall you presently: now landlady are you pleased with your asparagus?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: With the asparagus I am; and yet but half pleased neither, as my husband shall very well know.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well, we will leave you to talk with him about it: come sir let us into the house.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: But half pleased sweetheart?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p:
No indeed John Brittleware ; the asparagus has done its part; but you have not done your part John; and if you were an honest man John, you would make sir Hugh's words good of the asparagus, and be kinder to me: you are not kind to your own wife John in the asparagus way; you understand me: for ought
I see pompions are as good meat for such a hoggish thing as thou art.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Well, when we come at home beck, I know what I know.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: At home, is't come to that? and I know what I know: I know he cannot love his wife enough at home, that won't be kind to her abroad: but the best is I know what my next longing shall be.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: More longings yet! now out of the unsearchable depth of woman's imagination, what may it be?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: It begins to possess me already, still more and more: now 'tis an absolute longing, and I shall be sick till I have it.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: May I know it forsooth, tell it that you may have it.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: I dare tell it you, but you must never know that I have it.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: If you dare tell it.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Dare ; nay be as jealous as you will: thus it is, I do long to steal out of mine own house, unknown to you as other women do, and their husbands never the wiser, hither to this same sparagus garden, and meet some friend that will be kind to me.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: How, how!

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: In private; unknown to you, as I told you; 'tis ▪ unpossible I shall ever have a child else, and you so jealous over me as you are?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Art thou a woman and speak this?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Art thou a man, five years married to me; and ask me now if I be a woman?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Art thou so full of the devil to fly out in this manner ▪

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Why his horns fly not out of me to fright thee, do they?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: O for a hell that has not a woman in't?

div.head: Act 3. Scene 9.
div.stage: Enter a gentleman and a city wife.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Look you there John jealousy , there's an example before your eyes, if nothing hang i'your sight; there you may see the difference between a sour husband and a sweet natured gentleman! good heart! how kindly he kisses her! and how featly she holds up the neb to him! little heart! when will you be so kind to your own wife John.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Is that his wife think you?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: No, no, I know her, 'tis mrs. Hollyhock the precise draper's wife ; o, how my longing grows stronger in me: i see what shift soever a woman makes with her husband at home, a friend does best abroad.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Indeed my mrs. will not take this money, there wants two shillings.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: Why is my piece too light #?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Two light for the reckoning Mrs. it comes to two and twenty shillings, and this is but twenty.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Unreasonable; how can she reckon it,

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I know what you had sir, and we make no bills:

sp.speaker: Gen .
sp.p: Well fare the taverns yet, that though they cozened never so much, would down with it one way or other●e and their jacks, go again; now tell your mrs. And that will hinder her somewhat.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Not a jot sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Then tell her the countess of Copt ▪ hall is coming to be her neighbour again, and she may decline her trade very dangerously.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: My mrs. scorns your words sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: You. Rogue ▪

sp.speaker: Woman .
sp.p: Nay sweet coursin, make no uproar for my reputation's sake; here youth there's two shillings more, commend me to your mistress.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: She pays the reckoning it seems.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: It seems then he has been as kind to her another way.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How is't? I hope you are not wrangling now, but better pleased than so.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: No, no, sir Hugh, 'tis not the Sparagus can do't, unless the man were better:

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: But may i now be confident that i am almost a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Without that confidence you are nothing.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: There wants nothing now, but that you learn the rules and rudiments, the principles and instructions for the carriages, congees, and compliments, which we'll quickly put into you by practice.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: And then the spending the little rest of my money, and i am a clear gentleman, and may see my uncle.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Right, right.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: And I will write it, and crowd it into as many bonds as I can a purpose to write gentleman; Timothy Hoyden of Tanton — no, of London, gentleman: London is a common place for all gentlemen of my rank, is it not?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Excellent, do you not mark how finely he comes on?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: But as I hope to live and die a gentleman Mrs. what shi ' call, your reckoning was devilish dear #: s'dagger three pound for a few cuckoo pintles, they were no better I think.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Now you fall back again, and derogate from the condition of a gentleman most grossly, to think any thing too dear you eat or drink.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Pox on't, I had forgotten.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: When he has his rules and principles, which must be his next study, he will remember.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Pray let's about it quickly.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Now we'll go; but you forget me mistress.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: No indeed sir Hugh , here's two piece for last week and this.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: 'Tis well #: landlord and landlady will you go?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Would you would long to be at home once.

sp.speaker: Wife .
sp.p: Wife I do perhaps and to be here again, and there again; and here, and there , and here again ● and all at once.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Hey kicksy-wincy winsie.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: And I do long to go to Windsor too, to know if the prophecy is as true there, as he reported here.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How did you hear it goes forsooth?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: That all old women shall die, and many young wives shall have cuckolds to their husbands .

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I heard forsooth that all young wives should die that were pure maids when they were married.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: And none other?

sp.speaker: Mat
sp.p: 〈◊〉 report goes forsooth .

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: You speak very comfortably: it may be a long journey to the world's end yet.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: It seems you are not proscribed by the prophecy then?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I thank my destiny.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p:
My first work when I am complete gentleman shall be
to get them a child, and make 'em friends.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: A most gentlemanly resolution.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: And truly the city is much bound to such well affected gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Is it possible that half this can be true, that a half brother of mine can be made such an ass all over?

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: 'Tis all true, as I am a Cursen fellow Mr. Thomas, every word on't: ● scorn to lie in a syllabub I; what luck had I to meet you? I never thought to zee you at London.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: S'daggers death, it has as good as veezed me out o'my wits to think on't: was my vathers blood zo quaisome to him, (With a mischief to't) that he must let it out to be a gentleman, because his mother was one (By her own report:) for our own parts we neither know nor care where hence she come, nor whither she's gone, but dead she is) she brought my father a good purse of money, and kept another in store it seems, till she could keep't no longer, and then bestowed it well and wisely upon Chitty vace her zonne, to make him a gentleman, and told him what great house he come on by her side; for she was a striker forsooth, and 'gan directions to find an old uncle of his here in cuckold-shire, one Mr. striker: but virst she bade him put his self into fashion, and be sure to bear's self like a gentleman; and he has ta'ne a wise course to compass it, it zeems: I warrant he ha' made a fool of his voure hundred pound by this time.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: Ay, and o'his self too, as his coney catchers ha' handled him: and you had zeen't, you would ha' be pissed your self vor woe, how they blooded him.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ah.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: And then how they spurged his guts out.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ah.

sp.speaker: Colt.
sp.p: A bots light on 'em, 'twould ha' made a dog zick to zeet how like a scalded pig he looked.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: And then how they did veed'ne with a zort of slipslaps not all worth of mess of milk porridge to make him vine vorsooth.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ah.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: You'll zee zuch an altercation in him as never was zeen in a brother.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: But I won't zee'n yet as voule a clown, as I am, and as vine a gentleman, as he is, I have a trick i'my sconce to make a younger brother o'me.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: I that would be zeene now.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I have't, and 'tis a vine one, I came to London to seek the fool my brother, and ha' the same directions from our curate, (To whom my mother told all) that Tim had to find his uncle strikers house, and I ha' quired it out; and this is it, and thou zhalt zee what I chill do now: wh'are within.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Who would you speak with.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: By your leave vorsooth, I would speak with the Mr. of the house: I understand his worship's name is Mr. Striker.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: He is so sir, but he is not in case to buy any cattle at this time.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nor do I come to zell'n any; my coming is of a dead body's errand vorsooth.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: What strange fellow is this trow?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I ▪ pray vorsooth, and you be old enough (As it zeems you be) to remember when my mother was a maid, did you know a zuster of Mr. strikers that was married into Somersetshire ?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: What was her name I pray?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Her Cursen name was Audry, she zed, and a striker she as bevore she was married; but my father made a hoyden.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Hoyden.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes hoyden, zo I zay; there be very good vokes of th' name, as you shall well know; I cham one my self, and she need not be ashamed I wiss of the kin she come on, to hugger-mugger it as she did to her dying day.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Most wonderful, but is she dead?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes vaith she's dead, and as sumptuously buried, though I zay't, as any yeoman's wife within ten mile of Tanton, any time these ten and twenty year.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Pray what were you to her?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I tell you, my vather married her; and I should be her zonne I think.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Good heaven, how things will come about!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Coulter keep thy countenance Coulter, ▪ I'll make 'em believe I am her very natural zonne, and zee what will come on't.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: I'll keep my countenance, and zet a vace on't too and need be.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Your uncle striker at this time is very sick sir, but I will acquaint him with your desire: pray walk into the next ▪ room the while sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: If he should die now coulter, and make me his heir?

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: I marry Mr. so you might make a better journey on't then the gentleman your brother.

sp.speaker: Fris .
sp.p: This to me is the greatest wonder of all, that I am presently possessed of my Mrs. sullen sickness, which has e'en drawn him to death's door, and my mistresses unfortunable condition are nothing to this country Hoyden's relation:

div.head: Act 4. Scene 3.
div.p: O Mr. Touchwood, you are the welcomest gentleman that ever could come into so heavy a house.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: A stinking one it is I am sure: that nasty carrion thy Mr. is i'my nose already, I think I were best go no further.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Let not the sadness of this place dismay you.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: But is he dead already, ha?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Not altogether dead sir

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: The worse luck; and how does your mistress? ha, ha, ha, well well I say nothing.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: She is in bodily health sir, but very sad and much disconsolate, poor damsel.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Not for her grandsire, is she: if the worst dog he keeps howl for him, I'll worry sheep with mine own ▪ teeth, and truss for him; but why is she sad, prithee tell me● ha' ▪ ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I marvel at your mirth sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I would now give her a new gown, to tell me the true cause that I might save mine oath, and roar out my rejoicings: 'twas a devilish trick of the rascals to bind me by oath never to speak of it, but to those that should tell me of it first. I have such a coil to keep it in now: prithee tell me, what has the old traveller , that is now bound for the low countries, gi'n thy Mrs. in his will, canst tell?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Alas he is offended with her, she has displeased him in somewhat, that is the main cause of his mortal sickness.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: That's my boy, there boy, there, that was a home blow.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: She comes not at him sir, nor dares not see him: do you know any thing by her sir?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: No, no, no, not I, not I; 'sbones I bit my tongue too hard.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: If you do sir, would you would speak a good word for her, that he may die in charity with her.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: The jade jeers me, I'll stay no longer i'the house.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Nay good sir say not so, after so many messages and entreaties, by all the best o'the parish, and an exhortation made to you by the minister himself: did you vouchsafe to come, and will you now come short to see my master, now the doctors have given him over, and he is dying?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I confess 'twas my desire to see that dying that brought me hither: where is he? I'll hold my nose, and have at him.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I hope you will be friends with him now sir; for he's e'en a going.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Friends? I'll rather go with him, and fight it out by the way.

div.head: Act 4. Scene ▪ 4.
div.stage: Enter striker brought in a chair, curate.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Look you sir here he is.

sp.speaker: Touch,
sp.p: What up and in a chair?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Yes sir; he will not yield by any persuasion to die in his bed.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Then he may live to be hanged yet ▪ for ought I see.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: See sir, your neighbour Touchwood comes to be reconciled to you.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: You are quite besides the book sir dominae, I have no friends in hell to send to by him: no sir, I come to see him die, as he lived a hateful miscreant.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: Let me pray and beseech you to speak more charitably, or else not to offend the dying man with your presence.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Do I come to humour him, or you, or myself, think you: you that take upon you, and do rather go about to soothe him up in his sickness, than to fright him out of his pain, rather encourage him to live then rid the world of him, and his abominations.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: Best look into yourself sir: the worlds a stage, on which you both are actors, and neither to be his own judge.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: But he has played many vild and beastly parts in it, let him go, I would see his last exit, and hiss him out of it; hark, the ravens cry pork for him, and yet he dies not.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: O you are a hard-hearted man.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: My heart's not hard enough to break his, I would it were: where's your kind hearted mistress, fetch her, and try what she can do.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Huh, huh, huh,

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: What have you done sir?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: So, so, so, so it works, it works.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Out snarling hellhound my curse upon thee, and thy cursed son that has undone my niece and me: curse upon curse light on ye.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.p: O fearful.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: How heartily he prays; sure he is near his end.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: Pray sir depart, you are too uncharitable.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: My son undone thy niece: has he not done her think'st thou? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Huh, huh, huh: villain thou knowest what he has done; huh, huh.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I know not whether I know or no; tell me, and I'll tell thee.

lg.l: I'll tell you then that which you know already,
Although you keep it for a joy within you:
Your wicked son has by her own confession
Done that unto her, that unless he play
The honest man's part and marry her, he will
Full dear answer it in hell.

sp.speaker: Stri:
sp.p: Huh, huh, huh.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Speak English, has he lain with her?

lg.l: 'Tis so:
She has confessed it to her grandfather,
To me, and Mr. Pancridge here is made
Acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha .

lg.l: The virgin says
She is depusilated by your son.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Depusilated, ha, ha, ha.

lg.l: It is no laughing matter: therefore send
Speedily for your son, before the rumour
Make it ridiculous; as yet none knows it,
But we a slender few.
Will you direct
Your divine rhetoric there to him; and win him
But to entreat me in this case, and try
What I will say to't.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: Be persuaded sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: In this extremity I do entreat you that they may marry .

lg.l: I have my ends upon thee; quickly die,
And take thine own, thy base submission
Has rendered thee more odious, more loathsome
To me than all thy former villainies.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Huh, huh huh.

lg.l: And hark thee ere thou diest, for now thou'rt going :
Before my son shall wed that whore thy niece,
She shall bring all the hands of all the whoremasters
In city, court, and kingdom, (Black coats, and all)
I will spare none) unto a fair certificate
That she is clear of all men but my son,

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Huh, huh, huh.

lg.l: Nay more:
That she is clear of him too; and that he
Has never topped her in the way we treat of,
Before he wed her: for my son shall not ride
In his old boots upon his wedding night:
So, now die and sink
Into thy grave, to rid us of thy stink.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: I have not known such want of charity.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Unconscionable wretch, thou hast killed my Mr.

lg.l: Ugh, ugh, no Fid ugh hem! he has cured me:
I am light at heart again: he has cured me;
He has played the good physician 'gainst his will;
And a halter be his fee for't.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: The devil I have, and his dam it shall.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Ah hem! I am light at heart again.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: O damned old counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Well fare your heart old master.

lg.l: Though she prove bastard-bellied, I will own her,
Cherish, maintain, and keep her from thy son.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: O I could tear that tongue out.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Keep her child too.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Do, and her next, and fill thy house with bastards.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I'll hold 'em more legitimate than thy brood.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: What mean you gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: For thou, thy son, thy house is all a bastard.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Bear witness, he calls my house a bastard.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Touch
sp.p: I'll make thy house to smoke for't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Bear witness there, he says he will fire my house.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: For neighbourhood and charity speak lower.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: 'Tis petty treason; I'll be wi'ye there sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And hang thyself old scare crow.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Will you eat a piece of gingerbread for your wind sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Out witch.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: O murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I'll lay as many actions on thee as thou hast bones in that swine's foot of thine.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: My nails shall right me: I'll teach him to kick a woman.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: Hold mistress Friswood .

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: O villain kick a woman!

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Thou laidst this plot to murder me, thou man-killer.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Bloodsucker thou liest.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: Help from above, within, or any whence, in the name of sanctity I conjure you. Flectere si nequeo superos, acheronta movebo.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What's the matter? by your leave which is my zick uncle? are you scuffling for's money before he be dead.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: We'll part you with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Ha you your tenants, your clowns here brought in to butcher me?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Slave they are thine, brought in to spoil and rob me; I know 'He●n not.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: I fear I have conjured up fiends indeed, how infernally they look?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No sir, we come with no zick intendment on neither neither zide; but an you be Mr. striker, we are o'your zide, an't be to cut all the rest into potherbs.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: No, this is my Mr.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Zay but the word then, and have at 'em.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Had you your ambuscado for me?

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: They are a pair of the sedan mules I take it.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: Moils sir, we be no moils would you should well know.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: We be Cursen folk as good as your self, and get you out o'the house by mine uncle's leave here.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Your uncle, o brave.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Or if I baste you not well a fine, and lambskin your jackets till your bones rattle i'your hides, then zay cha bewrayed the house I come on.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p:
Well sir, I'll go and leave you to your uncle: rejoice
sir with your kind red: I hope you will have more shortly, if your niece prove fruitful: come master Paneridge, will you go?

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: With joy for your recovery, and manners to your privacy, right worshipful I leave you to talk with 'Clown your nephew.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Tarry, tarry; as sure as a club, this clown is sent for out of the country, to solder up his cracked niece in matrimony, and therefore calls him uncle; I could spoil the match, but by my oath I dare not; and therefore clown take thy course: come let us go Mr. Pancridge

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: And why you my nephew sir?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And why not I your nephew; han't she told you, and ha' not I told you as much as the matter's worth, and do ye mean to vlee from the bargain?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What new afflictions hourly find me out?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: And for your health, I hope sir.

lg.l: Sir, I'll have better testimony than your own;
'Tis true I lost a sister; but till you
Bring stronger proof she was your mother sir,
Your clownship must not uncle me; am I wi'you sir?
King's crowns have been pretended to by impostures;
And knavery is as rife in russet wool,
As in the proudest purple; get you gone,
There I am wi'you directly.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Is't come to this now?

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: Your project will not hold Mr. Thomas, best zeek your brother Tim, he has a certification from the parish, and the priest too, of all your mother's mind, and you could cozen him on't, and come again, and uncle this weese gentleman, whether he wool or no; 'twould be vine i'vaith

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Agreed: well sir, vor this time I ha' no more to zay t'ye, since you be so budge: but he that made you save you

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Farewell sir, I do begin to think there's something in't.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: He made me think he was your sister's son I am sure.

lg.l: I will not think so, no he was set on
By some of my maligners to abuse me;
it had been good to ha' laid him by the heels:
But let him go; call down my niece out of
The melancholy mist she's chambered in,Ex. fris.
All makes for her; their vexing me, restores
Her to my love again; and reason good;
She's mine own natural niece: and though
She has lost the husband, and the name she sought,
Yet she appears a striker; and I will cherish her.
Come you shall grieve no longer, I am friends wi'ye:
Stand up, stand up I say, and look up too,
Off with this mourning veil, and dry those tears:
I have considered that right noble parents
Have pardoned in their children as great faults;
But let it be your warning, not your licence.
For your security I am content,
And would entreat to live in that retirement,
Which your fair justice, and my foul offence
Of late confined me to, to weep and sigh
My loathed life away.
No more: you shall
No longer live reclused in wilful darkness;
Enjoy your former liberty; see, and be seen:
And (As you weigh my pardon and my love)
Let not your blemish dwell upon your face;
Nor any argument of grief, or shame
Be legible there, to the most curious eye:
But let your cheek be cheerful, and your brow
Crowned with as great a confidence, as may
Comply with virgin modesty: and that
Add to your beauty with full strength of art,
Beyond the eye to take a lover's heart.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: In all I will obey you,

lg.l: If I make
Choice of a husband for you then, you'll take him.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: 'Twill but become my duty.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: A good girl.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
Sir here's the knight come again, that has been here in the time of your sickness to have seen you, and my mistress, but
could not: and left a letter for you once: he that looks women through so.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: O ▪ sir Arnold cautious: did you tell him I was of the mending hand.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Yes I told him you were so, so.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Give me my gown and cap though, and set me charily in my sickly chair; his letter is a treaty of a match betwixt his nephew and my niece: go fetch him up.
In niece, and be not seen until I call you: until you hear me call you, do you hear?
Could I but catch this cautious coxcomb knight now — I'll put fair for't.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Here is the knight sir.

lg.l: Why reach you not a chair? I hope sir Arnold
You'll pardon the necessity of my rudeness:
I cannot rise, nor stoop, to you, uh, uh, uh.
Rather excuse me sir, that press upon you
Thus in your weakness: but you understand
My business by my letter if you have read it.
Yes sir, go forth; but be not far I pray you. Ex. Fris.
I have heard your nephew is a wild young man .
A very bashful boy I assure you; that's the reason
That I am won to be a spokesman for him.
O no dissembling sir; you know he is wild,
And suffers under your displeasure for't: uh, uh, uh.
A witch could not guess righter: but they say
That dying men are prophets oftentimes.
Suppose he has been wild, let me assure you
He's now reclaimed, and has my good opinion:
And is as like in person and behaviour
To gain the maid's affection.

sp.speaker: Stri,
sp.p: Speak to the purpose; pray what's his estate?

lg.l: Ay there's the point indeed: why sir, he has
A hundred pound a year; and is withal
A hopeful, and a handsome gentleman.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hopeful, and handsome! uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: You sir have wealth enough.

lg.l: And she has choice enough
Of greater matches: could I get her
Into a marriage vain, but she'll not look
Upon a man not she; but lives retired
Here in my house, and is a careful nurse:
She's fitter sir to be an old man's nurse,
Than any young man's bride: uh, uh, uh, uh.
Is she so grave in youth? I have often sought
A sight of her, but never could obtain it.
Not without my consent I warrant you;
She's nearer to a mother than a maid.
I tell you truth sir, and you know deceit
Becomes not dying men: uh, uh, uh. For virtue and obedience
She's fitter for yourself then for your nephew:
But to the point, a hundred pound a year
You say he has, and hopes and handsomeness,
Which may acquire, with your assurance of
So much for jointure — yes, a thousand pound
In portion with her: but sir let me tell you,
I'd rather give six thousand unto one
Of mine own choice; which she will not refuse,
If I but say this is the man, and take him.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Will not your niece be seen: I fain would see her.

lg.l: At hand: she will not out of my presence sir,
Nor ever was by man, not since the clock
Of her virginity struck eleven, not she,
Except at door or window, as men pass:
And so perhaps your nephew may have seen her.
Introth no otherwise; and so he told me .
May not I see her sir?
I tell you true;
Deceit you know becomes not dying men: uh, uh, uh.
And therefore hark you sir, I have a purpose,
(That if she take the man whom I will choose)
To make her my sole heir; provided that
She match before I die: uh, uh, I cannot last .

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Pray let me see your niece.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Friswood — why Friswood.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Is that her name?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: No sir, I call my maid.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: A maid; I took her for an old woman.

lg.l: A maid upon my virtue: and I fear
That her frigidity has mortified my niece:
Deceit becomes not dying men you know
Friswood I say, I bade her not be far:
I dare not strain myself to call her louder.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I'll call her for you sir: Fris —

lg.l: Hold sir, hold, pray use this whistle for me,
I dare not strain myself to wind it I,
The doctors tell me it will spend my spirits,Caut . whistles.
So, so, enough sir — fie, fie upon you:
Go call my niece, uh, uh.
Be of good cheer sir, and take courage man:
What you have been a striker in your days:
And may be again, I would not have him die.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Uh — alas I cannot last — why comes she not?

lg.l: I cannot get her from her work; nor to
Believe me that you sent for her, because
I told her that a gentleman was with you
There was your fault, than I must call myself.
Why Anna-bell, ah, ah, ah, An-na-bell.
Take heed, strain not yourself too hard, but send again:
The rarest beauty that I e'er beheld,Act 4. Scene 2.
Which with a maidenhead of that growth,Enter Annabell.
Would be an absolute wonder, her sweet modesty,
And meek obedience , justifies that too,She kneels at Striker's feet.
And makes her up a miracle of nature;
My former misbelief I do renounce,
And at first sight, (Which is the birth of love)
A faith grows in me, strengthened by the word
Of this expiring man, that chastity
Has not forsaken beauty.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You shall hear him.

lg.l: What to propound a husband? honoured sir,
Although I rather wish to die a virgin;
yet my obedience to your grave behests
Shall sway my will: your choice shall be my liking:
But let me thus much favour beg, before
You make that choice, that you will not destroy
The building you have reared ; your care and cost
Hath built me up by virtuous education,
Unto that height that I consider heaven;
And wax so old in that high contemplation,
That to look down on youthful vanities,
Were to be at a stand; and to delight in 'em,
Were to fall back again; and to be linked
In marriage, to a man whose wild affections
Are bent to worldly pleasures a main perdition.
I dare not speak to her for my nephew now:
Nor (Though I love her strangely) for myself.
Do you tell me of his nephew sir? even he
The knight himself, I hold to be too young
For a well governed man as the world goes.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I ha' not the heart to wrong her; she's too good.

lg.l: Sir, here's a gentleman presses at my heels
To speak with you.

div.head: Act. 4. Scene 8
div.stage: Enter Gilbert with his arm in a scarf.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Mr. Goldwire, what's your haste?

lg.l: I come to cry you mercy, and this good gentleman;
And this sweet gentlewoman, who I take it
Is his fair niece, of whom you are in treaty;
If it be not already gone too far;
Let me entreat you not to put your finger
Further i'the business in behalf of your nephew.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: You first moved me to't.

lg.l: 'Tis that repents me:
Your base unworthy nephew has abused me;
I do not speak it for a slight hurt he has gi'n me,
But for his breach of faith to another virgin.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: O me; and would you speak for such a man?

lg.l: And the false way, the plot he had upon you,
To put you on this enterprise, the quarrel ▪
in which he rescued you, to endear himself to you,
Was a mere counterfeit squabble, a very trick
Contrived betwixt him ▪ and his brother poet
T'abuse your goodness:
I leave it to your consideration sir:
I am in haste; and so I wish you health sir;
And you much happiness in a husband lady.
Has given me here a letter; I want but
Place fit to peruse it.
Had he a plot upon me, I'll have my plot too;
And now woe for myself sir if you please.
Sir, let me tell you, I think well of you, uh, uh,
Deceit becomes not dying men you know,
She would make e'en too good a wife for you:
For I have heard sir of your disposition,
Never to marry without best assurance,
First, of virginity, and then of chastity,
In her that you would choose; and let me tell you, uh, uh,
I know not where you can so well be fitted:
She's right, uh, uh, if you dare take a weak man's word,
Deceit would ill become me, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I take you at your word, and thank you sir.

lg.l: Uh, uh, uh, uh — oh lay me in my bed:
You need not leave me yet sir.
No sir, no,
It shall be a match, or no match ere I go.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Now sir have you your rules by heart?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Both rules and rudiments I have all ad unguem.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Repeat your principles.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p:
Principles to be imprinted in the heart of every new made gentleman: to commend none but himself: to like no man's wit but his own: to slight that which he understands not: to send money, and never look for't again: to take up upon obligation, and lend out upon affection: to owe much, but pay little #: to sell land, but buy none: to pawn, but never to redeem again: to fight for a whore:
to cherish a bawd, and defy a tradesman.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: And can you observe and keep these rules think you?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I hope I can sir, and have begun pretty well already : you see I have spent and lent all my money; and pawned all my clothes but these on ▪ my back, as I am a clear gentleman; and for the rest of the rudiments, and the several carriages and deportments by garb, by congee, compliment, etc. which are to be attained by practice when I come abroad and amongst 'em, you shall gain credit by me.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I commend your confidence: now Mr. spring, and Mr. Brittleware, play you the complementasters before him a little, for his further instruction: imagine them a couple of courtiers scarcely acquainted fall to; and look that you congee in the new French bum-trick; here landlord, take his cloak and hat to appear more generous.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Bum trick!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Come meet and begin; play but two or three bouts at most at single rapier compliment, and one or two at backsword and you ha' done: now observe sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Single rapier, and backsword compliment foil.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Noble master fine-wit, the single example of court-ceremony, if my apprehension deal fairly with me.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Sir, how auspiciously have I fallen upon the knowledge of you by virtue of the same apprehension.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: So, there's one.

div.head: Scene 10.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: What's here?

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.p: Peace, let's see a little more.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: As I am a gentleman, a neat bout and fairly come off of both sides.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Sir , I shall ever bless the promptness of my memory, in being so fortunate to collect the fallacious acquaintance of so complete a goodness.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Sweet sir I shall ever bless, etc.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p:
O you are pleased out of that noble worth which can convert all things to the form and image of its own perfection
to make yourself glorious, with that which is miserably impoverished in itself.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Good, there's two.

sp.speaker: Hoy,
sp.p: Miserably impoverished in itself — o sweet.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Sir, you have such a conquering way in humility, that he shall be sure to come off vanquished that offers to contend with you.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: This is the noblest of all humanity to piece up the defect of your friend with a glory of your own.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: A plain hit that: here were three bouts well played.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Piece up the defect of your friend with a glory of your own: most stately fine, as I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: So much for single rapier: now for your secret wipe at backsword.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I that I would see, like the hackling of the miller's legs: now for a delicate backblow.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: See you yond fellow I held compliment with?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Yes sir, a well-spoken gentleman and a lovely.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: The arrantst trifle in a kingdom.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: What he is not, is he?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Made only to make physic work: a very lump of laughter.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You have done well: now you sir.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Do you note him yonder that passed from you?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: That gallant sir?

lg.l: The very scorn at court;
So empty, not one passable part about him.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: A very tilting stock for young practisers to break their jests on.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Good and enough; do you call this good enough, to abuse one another thus?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Yes, this is quacksword compliment: this wipes off the false praise which the first thrust on: you must be seen in both, or you are no true garbist else.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I shall soonest hit o'this; for from a whelp I could give scurvy language.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Now break in upon 'em; save you sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: O course salutation: save you sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How got you hither gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Here we are sir, and have seen part of your practice, your courtly exercise.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Peace: but how got you in, and a stranger with ye?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: He shall betray nothing.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: We found fair entrance into the house.

div.stage: Gil. and Wat whisp. with Mon.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: 'Sfoot where's my wife then?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: If your wife be the gentlewoman of the house sir, she's now gone forth in one of the new hand-litters: what call ye it, a sedan.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: O Sedana.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: He's run mad with his horns.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: He's run with my hat and cloak by your leave.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: He'll come again, ne'er doubt him.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: You say so small acquaintance #; but I could never see any thing of mine again, since I came amongst you, if it once got out of my sight: what money have I left trow?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I pray gentlemen which way took she:

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Down towards the strand I tell you, in a new litter, with the number one and twenty in the breech on't.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: A litter of one and twenty in her breech: high time to run.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: You see we have our plot in action too, sir Hugh, and it runs fairly on.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: But what a rogue art thou to put such a slur upon thine own uncle #; first to put him on for thyself, than you with a counterfeit trick to put him off of that course, to run desperately headlong to break his own neck in a match: what a rogue art thou to use thine uncle thus?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Nay what a wretch were you, if you should cross your daughter in such a fortune?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Which if I do, cut my windpipe: what the young rascal Touchwood is gone into France they say?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Ay he's safe enough.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Sir cautious to be catched! if I do not love my daughter the better for her lucky leg stretching , I am a villain, I am taken with such kind of roguery.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Take heed you have not a cross plot in that itching pate of yours to spoil all now.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Then cut my weasand I say.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And I swear I will, or cut these hands off; I thought good to tell you so, because I know what tricks you have done, and what discoveries you have made for small parcels of ready money.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Hoo pox, I want no money; now look there comes Mr. Hoyden, salute these gallants.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: What without a hat or cloak?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: The better for a young beginner.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Sweet sir, I shall ever bless my auspicious stars, that shined me into the fallacious acquaintance of so singular goodness.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Sir you forget yourself.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Most singular sweet sir, most miserably impoverished in itself.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Good sir forbear, make not an idol of me.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: You piece up the defect of your friend with a glory of your own.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Can you say this gentleman was a clown within this fortnight?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Within this fortnight I assure you sir, as rank a clown of one side, as ever held cow to bull.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Had it been of both sides, it had been miraculous.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Now note me sir: do you see that fellow I left?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis my friend.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: The arrantest coxcomb in a country

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Made only to make physic work.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: You do not know him sure.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: A tilting stock for young practisers to break jests on: there's a wipe for you at back sword compliment.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: There's another for you sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: You knock at the wrong door sir, and I pity your ignorance: go to school as I have done, and learn more wit: kick a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: Here he is and here be all the crew on 'em, and more.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Here? thou mockest he is not here: sure these be all lords I think.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: How now; what's he?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Slid 'tis his clown brother he spoke of?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Is't possible? icha made a sweet jaunt after you and have I vound a vine fool o'thee: where's thy voure hundred pound? is that made a fool on too trow: where's the zartificate my mother give thee to find thine uncle? give me that, Chill see what I can do wi't.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Away clown I know thee not canst thou compliment?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Compliment lies, I can compliment dagger out o'sheath, an I zet on't.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: I hope he'll veeze you, and make your zilken jacket hum: well zed Mr. Thomas to 'em, and to 'em all I'll zide ye.

sp.speaker: Gil. Wat. Sam.
sp.p: Mr. Thomas does he call him?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Thomas, and what zay you to that; and as good a Mr. as the best o'ye, and you go to that; for by uds shall judge me, I think you are all but a company of cheaterlings; and if you do not give the fool my brother satisfaction for the wrongs you had one him, and me in him, I'll canvas it out of the carcases o'some o'ye, by uds daggers death will I. Draw coulter, and amongst 'em.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Hold sir, hold, you shall have satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: O shall I zoe, put up again coulter.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: This is a stout roaring clown.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Where's the Mr. of the house?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: He's run mad, after his wife, now he should look to his house.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Cha mich ado to vorbeare beating o'thee yet, my vingers do zo itch at thee.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I understand thee not, as I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: But now I think on't coulter, we'll have all again, and by a quieter way; and teach 'em to lick honey, catch birds with chaff, or go to blow with dogs.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; who understands the barbarian trow?

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: Uds vish master they do nothing but jeer to you all this while now.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Do they jeer, let 'em jeer and gibe too; I'll fetch ones warrant shall out jeer 'em all, and he be above ground.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You shall not need sir; go but in till the Mr. of the house comes home, you shall have your desire.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: You zay very well sir; zay well is good, but do well is better. Let's zee what you will do now.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Remember we have warned you sir Hugh, we must leave you.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nay I'll look to you: sirrah come in my hand.

lg.l: Now for a trick to rid us of this clown,
Or our trade sinks, and up our house is blown.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: 'Tis as I tell you Mr. Touchwood; your son has lost a fair fortune in the young gentlewoman, and as I conceive by your wilfulness sir Arnold cautions licks his lips at her. I assure you; and a sweet lick it is, six thousand pound in present portion.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: A sweet lick he has indeed if he knew all.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: He does know all sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: If he did, I know what I know; good oath let me not lose thy virtue.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: He knows moreover, that Mr. Striker, her grandfather has covenanted to give her two thousand pound more at the birth of his first child, lawfully begotten on her body.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; but what if her first child prove illegitimate?

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: That is not to be thought sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Yes, and spoken too, if I durst; but good oath let me not lose thy virtue.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: And then he had entered into ten thousand pound bond, to leave her his heir if she survive him.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: But he's well recovered you say.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Very lusty, very lively sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Then hang him, he'll never die; I am a feared I must be fain to give him over, I shall never vex him to death: no, no, I shall never do't.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: No sir, I heard himself say, that your vexing him has been his physic, and the best means to keep him alive.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Did he say so? I'll tear this match in pieces presently: and see how that will work on him; I'll do't, what's an oath to me, in respect of sending him to the devil, I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: I would you could sir, and recover her for your son yet.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Umh.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Because I love the young gentleman well

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Umh.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Though I assure you the writings are all passed, signed, sealed, and delivered; but I have 'em in my hands yet, and can do you a pleasure.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Humh.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: And came purposely to advise you, because I love your son.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Umh — what a world of villainy lies in the jobber nole of a lawyer.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Think of it sir, and be speedy.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Right learned in the law, and my son's friend Mr. trampler, Mr. Ambodexter trampler, you are a most notorious knave, and and you shall hear on't o'both sides, as you take fees.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Nay, and you be so hot Mr. Touchwood I am gone.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I know my course; either I will crack the heartstrings of striker, in crossing this match, with the cracked credit of his niece, or else I will be friends with him, and that will kill him out right: but my oath still troubles me — o gentlemen you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Ha you heard sir of your son yet?

lg.l: Not I, he lacks no money yet it seems:
Young travellers make no other use of their fathers.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: But ha you heard the news of his young mistress?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What of sir cautious being catched, the wise and wary gentleman, your uncle, that would not believe there could be a marriageable maid, though she were justified by a jury of midwives, and therefore purposed to have died a bachelor: that he should now be catched with a pipped nutshell, and a maggot in't.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Sure he was strangely wrought to't.

lg.l: Ay you must think
There have been knavish heads used in the business.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: But I will cross it and their knaveries, whate'er they are.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I hope you will not cross mine uncle in such a fortune though.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What to marry a wench?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: No, so much wealth sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Pray let me use my Christian liberty, my conscience pricks me to't, it must be done.
Now what say you sir?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: We might ha' spared this labour: he was resolved before we came it seems to spoil the marriage.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: We could not be too sure though: we are now sure enough, that our dissuasions will spur him on the faster.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And we are no less sure, that sir Hugh Money-lacks will set his strength to life sir cautious off o'the hooks, in hope of a matter of 5. Pound, though he forfeit the obligation of his throat by't.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: All the danger is, that sir Hugh will be with mine uncle too soon, and prevent the match before he be too deep engaged in't.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: For that my letter of instructions, which I have given Annabell shall prevent him; and striker keeps sir cautious in his house so warily, that until the intended wedding hour, sr. Hugh shall not obtain admittance.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Go fetch 'em in, and make the warrant: ha, ha, ha: gentlemen will you hear a complaint my man tells me of certain clowns that desire my warrant to apprehend for notorious cheaters, whom do you think?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I cannot guess.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I know none I hope.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Even sir Hugh Money-lacks, the mourning knight, and some of his associates.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: O'my life it is the roaring clown, about the new made gentleman his brother.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What is it you sir, Mr. strikers nephew, as I take it, you called his great worship's uncle lately as I take it, and did your best to tore me out of his house.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: 'Zheart Coulter we be vallen into the baker's ditch.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And do you bring your complaints to me sir, ha?

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: Zet a good vace on't; and veare no colours though.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I am an honest man, and a true man for all that, and I thought you the vittest to make my complaint to because you were the next justice, to as pestilence a piece of villainy as ever you were master of in all your life: I come but u●r justice, and to pay vor what I take, an't be avore hand, here it is, whether it be vor your clerk or your self, who makes or meddles with it, your man has my complaint in writing, pray let me have your warrant.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.p: You shall, but first tell me, how came it that you called that Striker uncle.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Warrant cause that he is uncle to a fool that I ha' to my brother, and I thought I might be so bold wee'n, and he was not against it at virst, till you were gone, and then he bade me go seek better testimony, and so I went and vound my brother Tim, his own zusters zonne I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: His sister's son?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Where he was made such a Tim, as never was heard on in Tonton, amongst a many cheaters: by mass here are a couple of 'em.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: These were o'the crew.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: How now my masters: sure fellow thou art mistaken.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No sir, I am not mistaken I but I take 'em ay, where I find 'em I: and I charge your justiceship with 'em ay, till they bring out my brother I.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Bring out your brother: why what has your brother done?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Done: nay they have done and undone him amongst 'em. And I think devoured him quick too vor he is lost, and nowhere to be vound.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Do you know the meaning of any of this gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: If he were your brother sir, that you found at sir Hugh Money-lacks lodging, you know we left him in your hands.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: We stepped in but by chance, and such a youth we found there, and there we left him in your and their hands, that had the managing of him.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Zo you did, but what then did me the rest, but plied me, and my man Coulter here with wine, and zack, and something in't, I dare be zwore that laid us a zleep, when we mistrusted nothing but vaire play: o speak coulter, o.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: And then when were vast asleep, they all gave us the slip, the knight was gone, and the squire was gone, and Mr. Tim was gone, but he was made away, without all peradventure; for all the 'parel that he wore was left behind: and then — speak master.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And then the Mr. o'the house came home, and made a monstrous wonderment for the loss of his wife; he could not find her he zed. and zo he vaire and vlatly thrust us out o'doores, and is gone a hunting after his wife again: speak coulter.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Alas poor Britleware.

sp.speaker: C●uli.
sp.p: And then we came for your warrant, to vind all these men again.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And to take 'em where we find 'em, and these were zome on 'em, when time was, and pray look to 'em.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I know not what to make o'this but sure there's something in't: and for these gentlemen I'll see them forthcoming.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: We thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And I will undertake sir Hugh Money-lacks will be at the bridehouse.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And thither will I instantly.

sp.speaker: Gil. Wat.
sp.p: We'll wait upon you sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And I chill make bold to wait upon you till I be better certified.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: You shall, come on your way, come gentlemen.

lg.l: Well, here is such a knot now to untie,
As would turn Oedipus his brain awry.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: Be appeased and comforted, good Mr. Britleware, trouble not your head in running after your fate, nor break your weighty brains in seeking ways after your wives heels, which are so light by your own report, they cannot crack an egg.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Her credit yet they may and mine.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: Besides your wife is your wife where'er she is abroad as we as at home, yea, lost perhaps as well as found: I am now going to yoke a heifer to a husband, that perhaps will say so shortly: whither away Mr. trampler?

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: To the wedding house: where I think I saw your wife last night Mr. Britleware.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Did you sir, did you●

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: I cannot say directly; but I think 'twas she: does she not call the gentlewoman aunt that keeps Mr. strikers house?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Yes mistress Friswood, she is her aunt sir.

div.head: Scene 6.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: Come go with us and find her.

div.stage: Enter the sedan, Hoy. in it, in woman's clothes.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Pray gentleman stay, for I suppose she's here here's number one and twenty; and this is sure the litter.

sp.speaker: Litter-man.
sp.p: What peep you for; you ought not to do so sir.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: By what commission ought you to carry my wife in a close stool under my nose

sp.speaker: Litter-man.
sp.p: 'Tis a close chair by your leave: and I pray forbear, you know not who we carry.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I know the clothes she wears, and I will see the party.

sp.speaker: H●y.
sp.p: I know that voice, and let me see the man; it is my surgeon.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: A surgeon! I took you for a china shopkeeper master Britleware; these by trades are for some by purposes, and I smell knavery.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: And lawyers commonly are the best upon that sent.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Gentlemen this is a man that lay in my house.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: A gentleman you would say, or my cost was ill bestowed there.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: These are my goods he wears; that was my mother's gown, and feloniously he wears it.

sp.speaker: H●y.
sp.p: 'Tis all I have to show for four hundred pound I laid out in your house; and sir Hugh put it upon me, and hired these men to carry me — whither was it?

sp.speaker: Litter-man.
sp.p: Up to a lodging in st. Giles's sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Where he promised to finish his work of a gentleman in me, and send me to my uncle.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: O monstrum horendum; a man in women's clothes.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: 'Tis felony by the law.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Has sir Hugh gi'en me the slip to finish his work in private? it shall all out, I am resolved, though I bewray myself in't: pray gentlemen assist me with this party to Mr. justice strikers, you say my wife is there.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Yes you shall thither.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: And there I'll take a course you shall smell knavery enough.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I find I am abused enough of conscience: and shall be carried to mine uncle now before my time and not as a gentleman, but as a gentlewoman, which grieves me worst of all.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: Hinc illae lachrimae, the youth is sure abused indeed.

sp.speaker: Hoy
sp.p: Oh.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Come leave your crying: and you beasts up with your luggage, and along with us; I'll fetch such drivers as shall set you on else.

sp.speaker: Litter-man.
sp.p: Let us be paid for our labour, and we'll carry him to Bridewell, if you please.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: O, o, that ever I was born in this groaning chair.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: It was well I sent for thee niece, to help me deck the bride here; and that the jealous fool thy husband thinks thou art gone astray the while; it will be a means for thee to take thy liberty another night, and pay him home indeed, when he shall not have the power to mistrust thee: it is the common condition of cuckolds to mistrust so much afore hand, that when they are dubbed indeed, they have not a glimpse of suspicion left.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Their horns hang in their light then; but truly aunt, for mine own part, I had rather my husband should be jealous still then be cured in that right kind; though I confess the ends of all my longings, and the vexations I have put him to

lg.l: Were but to run his jealousy out of breath,
And make him pant under the frivolous weight
He bears; that is, a cuckold in conceit;
Which without doubt he labours with by this time:
And when he finds me clear, 'twill be as well:
(I hope) and better than if it were done
By the broad way of foul pollution.
Nay I do not persuade you, take the downright way,
nothing against your conscience niece; I sent
For him to ha' come and found you here by chance;
But he has shut up house, and is run mad
About the town I hear to all your haunts.
He shall come hither and renounce his jealousy,
And then entreat me too before I go.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Yes, that's a wise wife's part.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What's the bride ready?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Yes sir, she's dressed.

lg.l: And dressed, and dressed indeed;
Never was maid so dressed: o sir you are happy;
The happiest knight, and are now in election
Of the most sweet encounter in a bride,
That e'er your chivalry could couch a lance at.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I thank you Mrs. and I'll bring her shortly to bestow money wi'ye in China wares.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: She is herself the purest piece of purslane — that e'er had liquid sweet meats licked out of it.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: And purer too I hope.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Go call her down.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: She's at her private prayers yet sir, she.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: When she has done, then hasten her away.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Such brides do seldom make their grooms their prey.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Do you now conclude sir Arnold you are happy?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: As man can be being so near a wife.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: By your leave gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: He come? I fear a mischief.

lg.l: How comes it father striker, and son cautious in election
That you huddle up a match here for my child,
And I not made acquainted, as unworthy,
Until the very intended marriage hour?
Who sent you hither, I sent not for you now sir:
And there I am with ye sir.
'Tis true, I covenanted not to come at you,
Until you sent for me, unless you found
Young Touchwood had the love of Annabell,
You have heard he has touched her has he not?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Has he not made her Touchwood too?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Can you say so?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Yes, and struck fire too in her tinderbox.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You will not speak thus.

lg.l: To you I need not; for you know't already;
But to my friend sir cautious, whom I honour,
And would not see so shipwrecked, I may speak it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Will you undo your daughter?

lg.l: My daughter; no you shall not put her upon me now.
She is your daughter sir: if I but call her mine,
Or suffer her to ask me a bare blessing,
You'll thrust her out: no, you adopted her
In your own name, and made a striker of her,
No more a money-lacks.
The beggarly knight is desperate,
And should he out with it, my shame were endless:
This is the way or none to stop his mouth:
'Tis but a money matter; stay a little

sp.speaker: Mon
sp.p: Go not away sir Arnold, I must speak with ye.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I am not going sir.

lg.l: Be not a madman here, here's forty pieces,
I know you use to strike for smaller sums:
But take it for your silence, and withal
My constant love, and my continual friendship.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Give me your hand of that; enough. Sir Arnold.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: What say you to me sir Hugh?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What does he mean trow?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You must not have my daughter.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: No sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Unless you mean to take another's leavings.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: O devilish reprobate.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: How mean you that?

lg.l: Till she has buried first another husband,
And he leave her a widow: I am her father,
And claim a father's interest in her choice;
And I have promised her to one already,
This very day, because I was not privy
To your proceedings; and have taken here
This fair assumpsit forty pieces sir;
You might admire how I should have 'em otherwise.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Here's an impudent villain.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: For these I give a hundred, if you wed her.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: To show my love unto your daughter sir I'll pay't.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Security in hand were good.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Pray lend me sir a hundred pieces.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I dare not cross this devil, I must fetch 'em.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: 'Twill never the less be my disparagement.

lg.l: What, when they know her grandfather disposed her,
That has the care of her, and gives her portion?
And then he can ha' but his money, can he?
O but the wench, the wench, is such a wench,
Scarce two such married in a diocese,
In twice two twelve months, for right and straight ones.
There said you well; the straight ones I like well:
But those that men call right, or good ones, suffer
A by construction.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Amongst the lewd.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: But is here weight and number sir?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Now the fiend stretch thee — you may take my word.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Here I am with ye sir.

div.head: Scene 11.
div.stage: Enter Gilbert, Wat, Touchwood, Tom, Sam.

lg.l: Though you are fully bent to cross the marriage,
Yet let's entreat you not to be too sudden.
Till they come to the word, for better, for worse
I will not touch at it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: How now, what mates break in upon us here?

lg.l: I come not as a guest sir, or spectator
To your great wedding, but o'the King's affairs;
In which I must crave your assistance sir;
Deny't me, or my entrance, if you dare.
It is some weighty matter sure then.
But not to trouble your sconce with too much business
At once, pursue your own, we will attend a while.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: So it is sir,

lg.l: In that he has said well: I would the bride
And priest were come once; I am content they stand
For witnesses: what my kind nephew are you here?
I thank you for your plot, you see what 'tis come to.
'Tis not all finished yet sir.
All in good time: the bride is coming now.
You and your brother poet are grown friends I see.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: But it may be

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What's he?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: A friend of Wat's he brought for company.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: He was amongst 'em too at the cheating exercise, and yond's the knight himself; I know 'em all I trow.

lg.l: And you'll stand to this, that your lost brother
Was strikers sister Audreye's son.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
I ha' told you twenty times, and yet because you zay you'll stand my friend, I'll tell you more, she was with child with Tim bevore my father married her (She brought him in her belly vrom this
town here (Where they get children without veare or wit) but vor her money, and's own credit's zake, my father was well paid to keep it vor his own; and nobody knew to the contrary, not Tim himself to this hour.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Then how cam'st thou to know it?

sp.speaker: T●m.
sp.p: My father told it me upon his deathbed, and charged me on his blessing, never to open my mouth to man, woman, nor child, zo I told nobody but vokes on't.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Well, hold thy peace, 'tis an absolute wonder! Now to the wedding

div.head: Scene 12
div.stage: Enter curate, Tramp. Ann. Fris. Reb.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: How's this? my bride in mourning habit, and her head in willow?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What's the meaning of it?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: I said she was dressed as never bride was dressed.

lg.l: A solemn show, and suiting well the scene!
She seems round bellied, and you mark it too.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: My habit and my dressing suits my fortune.

lg.l: Pray sir do your office, her conceit
We will know afterwards.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: Hem, hem.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: O, o.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: O me; why mistress look up, look up I say.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Clap her cheek, rub her nose.

sp.speaker: Fris
sp.p: Sprinkle cold water on her face.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Cut her lace, cut her lace, and bow her forward, so, so, so.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I'll lay my life she quickens now with child.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Oh.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: What think you is the matter?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Women how is it with her?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Sir, as with other women in her case.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: How's that I pray you. you have been doing something aforehand sir.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: 'Twill out, 'twill out,

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Have I?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: It seems so by the story.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Is she so dressed?

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: You may leave laughing, it was your son that did it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I am undone, my house disgraced for ever.

lg.l: He knew't before hand, now I may declar't,
Speak of thy conscience, did it not?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: O my heart.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: O the hangman.

lg.l: Deceit becomes not dying men you know,
Into a whirlpool of confusion
Sink thou and all thy family, accursed miser.
This was a sure way now sir cautious,
To marry a maid, there's one i'the mother's belly.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Uh, uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: You knew not where I could be so well fitted.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: A rot o'your dissembling entrails, spit 'em out, you durst not strain yourself to wind your whistle, your doctor told you it would spend your spirits, so made me whistle for her

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Uh, uh, uh.

lg.l: Cheer up, cheer up, I may be friends wi'ye now:
Here's one has cause, and knows the way to vex ye,
To preserve life in you as well as I.
A hem, a hem, I will outlive you both:
This day's vexation is enough for a life time.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: And may it last thee to thy lives last hour.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Now let me talk wi'ye, and come you hither sir.

lg.l: I tell you true, your writings are so past, that if you go
Not off by composition, you'll shake your whole estate.
Come hither nephew,
I'll give thee a thousand pound, and take her off me.
I cannot with my reputation now:
But I will do my best to work a friend to 't.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Prithee do, try thy poetical soldier.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: That clown come hither too: I fear I am trapped.

lg.l: 'Tis all as I have told you, and without question,
The man in question is your sister's son.
Would it might prove so, that I had yet a nephew,
For now my niece is lost.
Here's one shall find him out: or stretch a neck for't.
Sir Hugh you are charged for making of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Now I am in.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.p: And more than so, for making him away.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: What gentleman?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Marry my brother Tim.

lg.l: Your patience yet a while: now gentlemen all,
Sir cautious, and the rest, pray hear a story:
I have been often urged to yield the cause
Of the long quarrel twixt this man and me:
Thirty years growth it has, he never durst
Reveal the reason; I being sullen would not.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You will not tell it now?

lg.l: Indeed I will:
He had a sister (Peace to her memory)
That in my youth I loved, she me so much,
That we concluded, we were man and wife;
And dread less of all marriage lets, we did
Anticipate the pleasures of the bed.
Nay it shall out; briefly, she proved with child:
This covetous man then greedy of her portion,
(Of which for the most part he was possessed)
Forces her with her shame to leave his house.
She makes her moan to me, I then (Which since
I have with tears a thousand times repented)
Against my heart stood off, in hope to win
Her dowry from him: when she gentle soul
(Whom I must now bewail) when she I say,
Not knowing my reserved intent, from him and me,
From friends, and all the world, for ought we knew,
Suddenly slipped away: after five years
I took another wife, by whom I had
The son, that has done that the woman says:
But where I left, if this man's tale be true,
She had a son, whom I demand of you.
I shall have a kind of an uncle of you anon,
And you prove Tim's father.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: The young gentleman that sir Hugh had in handling, is in the house, and master Brittleware with him.

sp.speaker: Curate
sp.p: Only we kept 'em back, till our more serious office were ended.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Pray 'em in, let's see him.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Sir, will it please you first to see a match quickly clapped up? This gentleman whom I know every way deserving, were your niece now in her prime of fortune and of virtue, desires to have her, and she him as much.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: He shall not have her.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: How can you say so?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: He knows his son I fear.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: My son shall make his fault good, and restore her honour to her if he lives, in meed for your fair sisters wrong and my misdeed, my son shall marry her; provided that he take her in his conscience unstained by any other man.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: On that condition I'll give her all the worldly good I have.

sp.speaker: Sam. Ann.
sp.p: We take you at your word.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: My son!

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I take her not with all faults, but without any least blemish.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: My supposed slain: thus I cast from me.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: 'Snails a cushion, how warm her belly has made it.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: And that all was but a plot 'twixt him and me, and these gentlemen: this paper may resolve you.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: 'Tis mine own hand by which I instructed her by a dissembled way, to wound her honour.
