lg.l: Which, to preserve my love, again I'd do,
Hoping that you forgive it in me too.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Now am I cheated both ways.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: The plot is finished: now thanks for your thousand pound sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: You are mine own; welcome into my bosom.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Whoop, who comes here, my brother Tim dressed like master mayor's wife of Taunton-dean.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: 'Tis all I could get to scape without of the cozening house; and all I have to show of four hundred pound; but this certificate and this small jewel which my dying mother ga' me; and I had much ado to hide it from the cheaters, to bring unto mine uncle; which is he?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Let's see your token sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: This is a jewel that I gave my Audrey.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: That was my mother.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And that's your father he zaies.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: And a gentleman? what a devilish deal of money might I ha' saved! for gentlemen let me tell you, I have been cozened black and blue; back-gulled and belly-gulled; and have nothing left me but a little bare compliment to live upon, as I am a clear gentleman.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Will you bestow some of it upon me.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Uncle you shall: first I'll give you a hit at single rapier compliment: and then a wipe or two with the backsword compliment and I ha' done.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Pray begin.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Noble Mr. Striker the grave magistrate (If my apprehension deal fairly with me) whose praises reach to heaven, for the fair distribution of equal justice: the poor man's sanctuary, the righter of widow's, and the orphan's wrongs.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Enough, enough, you have said very well.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Note you yond justice sits upon the bench?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Yes, I do note him.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p:
The stocks were fitter for him: the most corrupted fellow
about the suburbs, his conscience is stewed in bribes, all his poor neighbours curse him; 'tis though the keeps a whore now at three score.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: A very western soothsayer, thou art mine own.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: His niece is much suspected.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Nay there you went too far, this is his niece, and my daughter now.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I know no niece he has, I speak but backsword compliment.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You put me well in mind though, here's one, that ere the parson and we part, I'll make an honest woman.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And for your part sir Hugh, you shall make satisfaction, and bring in your confederates.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Here's one that came to complain of me for my robes here, but I ha' lost my small acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I'll answer for him too, and give you all the satisfaction that I can

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What you cannot shall be remitted, we have all our faults.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: And have I found thee beck in so good company?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Ay Jack, be you jealous no more, and I will long no more to vex thee.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Live lovingly and honestly I charge you, or come not at me when I am married.

lg.l: This younker I'll take care for,
And make him a new gentleman by new breeding,
Without the diet, bathing, purge, or bleeding.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Sweet sir I thank you.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I'll home again then and make Tanton ring on't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Our quarrel in this piece of folly ends.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: He parted us, and he has made us friends.

lg.l: Nephew, and gentlemen, I am friends with all,
You had your plot upon me, I had mine.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Let's in, and end all differences in wine.

lg.l: At first we made no boast, and still we fear,
We have not answered expectation here,
Yet give us leave to hope, as hope to live,
That you will grace, as well as justice give.
We do not dare your judgements now: for we
Know lookers on more than the gamesters see;
And whate'er poets write, we act, or say,
'Tis only in your hands to crown a play.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
